urn:contentItem:6CWB-K7C1-JBSP-12GK-00000-00Reports Outline Thermal Engineering Findings from School of Civil Engineering (Characteristics of Concurrent Flame Spread Over Convex Charring Materials)2024-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisENGINEERING - THERMAL ENGINEERINGReports Outline Thermal Engineering Findings from School of Civil Engineering (Characteristics of Concurrent Flame Spread Over Convex Charring Materials)


2024 SEP 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Engineering Daily News -- Investigators discuss new findings in Engineering - Thermal Engineering. According to news reporting out of Changsha, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "In real forest fire scenarios, there are a large number of convex and concave terrains at the junction of flat land and slopes. In this paper, a typical charring material, kraft paper, is selected as the experimental sample, and the variation law of key characteristic parameters of flame spread over convex solid surface are investigated."


Financial support for this research came from National Science Foundation of Hunan Province.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the School of Civil Engineering, "The experimental results show that all the flame spread processes have obvious deceleration behaviors, and the influence mechanism of flame tangent angle on the flame spread deceleration of convex surfaces is revealed. The characteristic length of the pyrolysis zone shows a tendency of increasing and then decreasing with time. The variation curves of radiant heat flux present two peaks. Combining with the characteristic length, the reason for the occurrence of two peaks is explained. The exponential relationship between the instantaneous mass loss rate and the characteristic length of the pyrolysis zone is obtained. Based on the range of power exponents, the heat transfer controlling mechanism in the pyrolysis zone is classified into three categories for all the working conditions. Moreover, a piecewise power-law relationship between the dimensionless maximum flame height and the dimensionless heat release rate is established."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The results of this study will fill the research gap of flame spread of solid materials with curved surfaces, and will be of great academic value for the improvement and development of theories on building and forest fire safety."
For more information on this research see: Characteristics of Concurrent Flame Spread Over Convex Charring Materials. Case Studies in Thermal Engineering, 2024;61. Case Studies in Thermal Engineering can be contacted at: Elsevier, Radarweg 29, 1043 Nx Amsterdam, Netherlands.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Yang Zhou, Cent South Univ, School of Civil Engineering, Changsha 410075, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Xiaonan Zhang and Xu Yan.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.csite.2024.104854. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Changsha, People's Republic of China, Asia, Thermal Engineering, Engineering, School of Civil Engineering.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2024, NewsRx LLC

urn:contentItem:6FN5-M173-RRH6-K291-00000-00Potential Hurdles Blocking Ukraine-Russia Peace Deal; 19-Year-Old Accused of Arson in New Jersey Wildfire Allegedly Left Bonfire Burning; Civil Rights Lawyer Says Trump is Going After "Ability to Interrogate Inequality"; Couple Financially Strained Paying Mortgage on Home Destroyed By Hurricane; Will Catholic Church Look to Pope Francis as a Model for the Next Leader?; Bison Herd Stops Traffic as it Crosses Road in Yellowstone, CBS2025-04-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisCBS EVENING NEWS PLUS7:00 PM ESTJanai Nelson, Matthew BerriosNEWSInternational042401cb.411Potential Hurdles Blocking Ukraine-Russia Peace Deal; 19-Year-Old Accused of Arson in New Jersey Wildfire Allegedly Left Bonfire Burning; Civil Rights Lawyer Says Trump is Going After "Ability to Interrogate Inequality"; Couple Financially Strained Paying Mortgage on Home Destroyed By Hurricane; Will Catholic Church Look to Pope Francis as a Model for the Next Leader?; Bison Herd Stops Traffic as it Crosses Road in Yellowstone, CBSMaurice DuBois, Nancy Cordes, Ray Strickland, Dave Malkoff

President Trump issued a rare public rebuke of Russian President Vladimir Putin following a deadly strike on Kyiv. The attack killed at least 12 and injured about 90 others. A 19-year-old man faces arson charges related to the wildfire in Ocean County, New Jersey, that has scorched more than 15,000 acres. Civil rights groups are condemning President Trump for signing a series of executive orders that they say could weaken anti- discrimination laws. When a natural disaster strikes, it can create a financial storm for homeowners who have lost everything. Dave Malkoff reports that many are often left temporarily homeless and still obligated to pay their monthly mortgage. As mourners converged to pay respects to Pope Francis, John Dickerson stopped to by the St. Patrick`s Catholic American Parish, where Father Matt Berrios spoke about what made the leader stand out from the rest. On a recent trip to Yellowstone National Park, tourist Cindy Shaffer captured the unique moment when a herd of bison stopped traffic for nearly 20 minutes.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

MAURICE DUBOIS: Welcome to CBS EVENING NEWS PLUS, I`m Maurice DuBois in for John.

"Vladimir, stop!" The words of Donald Trump in a rare rebuke to the president of Russia as Moscow pounds Ukraine`s capital with one of its largest aerial bombardments of the war. Nancy Cordes will join us with the latest.

A New Jersey teenager is arrested for setting the state`s largest wildfire in nearly 20 years. The smoke now impacting air quality in New York City. CBS` Ray Strickland reports for us tonight.

And in-depth tonight, imagine being homeless and saddled with a mortgage. CBS` Dave Malkoff looks into how this is possible. Those stories and more right after our news headlines.

A federal judge in Maryland has ordered the return of yet another man deported to that prison in El Salvador. The district judge who was appointed by President Trump says the administration violated an agreement to protect the Venezuelan migrant from deportation, while his case for asylum is being heard.

Long simmering tensions between nuclear armed India and Pakistan are escalating, following a deadly attack on civilians in Kashmir, which India controls, but both countries claim as theirs. India blamed Pakistan for the assault, which killed 26 mostly Indian tourists in the region. A previously unknown group calling itself Kashmir Resistance is claiming responsibility.

And a key measure of the country`s economic health, sales of existing homes took a drubbing. They tumbled by nearly 6% in March. It`s the biggest single month drop in three years, but the average rate on a 30-year mortgage eased slightly this week to 6.81%. That`s below the more than 7% rate this time a year ago.

We begin tonight with the hurdles to get to a possible peace deal between Russia and Ukraine. President Trump issued a rare public rebuke of President Putin following a deadly strike on Kiev. The attack Thursday morning killed at least 12 and injured 90 others, the deadliest assault on Ukraine`s capital since July.

Chief White House correspondent Nancy Cordes joins me now. And Nancy, what we`re hearing from the president on a possible peace deal here and his recent airstrikes. After all, the president was talking about ending this war on day one.

NANCY CORDES: Right. Well, that deadline has come and gone, Maurice, but the president does still believe that he can broker some kind of deal between Russia and Ukraine as long as it happens fairly quickly. He did express frustration with the Russians again publicly today, saying that he felt that it was not helpful for Vladimir Putin to target civilian locations in Kyiv, leading to the deaths of Ukrainians even as these talks continue.

But he also lashed out at the Ukrainian leader, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, arguing that what Zelenskyy wants, particularly when it comes to the Crimean Peninsula, is unrealistic. And interestingly, when he was asked, Maurice, what he thinks Russia is prepared to give up in this negotiation, he basically made it sound like he doesn`t expect Russia to give up much at all. Take a listen to that exchange from the Oval Office.

(Begin VT)

REPORTER: What concessions has Russia offered up thus far to get to the point where you`re closer to peace?

DONALD TRUMP (R) (U.S. President): Stopping the war, stopping taking the whole country, pretty big concession.

(End VT)

NANCY CORDES: So if that`s what`s on the table, is Russia basically agreeing not to continue this war, but taking all of the territory that it has so far, that`s something that is unlikely to be palatable, Maurice, to the Ukrainians.

MAURICE DUBOIS: Nancy, as you update us on where negotiations stand, I heard the President saying in the Oval today, we are putting a lot of pressure on Russia. You have no idea. What exactly does that mean? Where do things stand? Anybody have any idea?

NANCY CORDES: Well, we do know that the President is sending his Middle East envoy, Steve Witkoff, to meet with Vladimir Putin in Russia on Friday, at least that`s the plan right now. The Russian Foreign Minister confirmed that to our Margaret Brennan in an interview today. But there was supposed to be another high-level meeting involving the Ukrainians in London. That was canceled at the last minute.

The Secretary of State decided not to go, and the assumption is that they didn`t like what Ukraine`s leader was saying about the fact that he didn`t think that he should have to give up territory.

MAURICE DUBOIS: Okay. Nancy Cordes at the White House. Thank you. As we turn now to the massive wildfire in New Jersey, traced back to a bonfire left burning by a 19-year-old who police say then fled the scene. The fire still rages, and it`s causing air quality concerns. CBS` Ray Strickland reports tonight from near the fire zone.

(Begin VT)

RAY STRICKLAND (voiceover): Firefighters are racing to put out a wildfire burning near Shore towns in Ocean County, New Jersey, that`s already destroyed more than 15,000 acres. It`s the Garden State`s largest fire in nearly two decades. Officials say it`s been difficult to keep this fire under control.

BILL DONNELLY (New Jersey Forest Fire Service Chief): We just could not get far enough ahead of this fire, based on its behavior, that we were able to actually keep it in check.

RAY STRICKLAND (voiceover): Nineteen-year-old Joseph Kling is accused of starting the fire on Tuesday. Authorities say Kling lit wooden pallets for a bonfire and left the area. Investigators used advanced equipment to track him down.

MAN: There was some technology that was involved, the GPS coordinates, we were able to establish, and that really led us to Joseph Kling and some of the witnesses that we were able to find.

RAY STRICKLAND (voiceover): This home and several buildings were damaged as the fire spread rapidly due to high winds, dry brush, and low humidity. Evacuations have now been lifted after some 5,000 people were forced to flee.

WOMAN: Didn`t sleep all night, and then we got the notice that we could go back, but it`s still very unsettling because look at it.

RAY STRICKLAND (voiceover): Firefighters are making progress. The blaze is now about 50% contained, but winds are blowing the smoky air towards New York and Long Island, creating health concerns for millions of people. Officials in New York have issued an air quality alert.

MAYOR ERIC ADAMS (D-NY): New Yorkers may see smoke and smell smoke over the city. We`re monitoring the situation closely and coordinating with New Jersey and New York State.

(End VT)

RAY STRICKLAND: And Kling now faces multiple counts of arson. He has not entered a plea. As large as this fire is, only one business and a few structures were destroyed.

Maurice?

MAURICE DUBOIS: Okay, Ray Strickland in South Jersey on the fire lines. Thank you.

Those civil rights groups are condemning President Trump for signing a series of executive orders this week that they say would weaken anti- discrimination laws.

Janai Nelson joins me now. She`s the President of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. Janai, good to see you.

So one of the executive orders goes after what is known as disparate impact liability. Take us through what that is and an example, if you can, of how that`s helped people in the past.

JANAI NELSON (President, NAACP Legal Defense Fund): Yeah, so it`s so important that we don`t get tripped up on these words disparate impact liability. What this is really about is the ability to interrogate inequality. When we see inequality and we see different groups experiencing a law or a policy in different ways, we as a society that believes in fairness, that believes in justice, we have an obligation to interrogate that.

To make sure that the results that we`re seeing are not based on discrimination, are not based on, you know, someone`s identity, and that they are fair policies. That`s what disparate impact means. It`s the ability to interrogate inequality.

We see this in so many spheres of society. So for example, if people are trying to access affordable housing and there`s a rule or a law, like a credit report threshold that somehow is making it difficult for people to find access to housing, to get shelter, then we should ask, is that really a useful tool to ensure who gets access to housing or not? If it is, then that`s fine.

If it`s not, and it`s hurting particular populations more than others, then we should be interrogating it. We should be making sure that we are not forcing inequality on people simply because of their identity based on policies that don`t serve us.

MAURICE DUBOIS: Whether it`s intentional or not is a key here too. What`s your biggest concern?

JANAI NELSON: That`s right.

MAURICE DUBOIS: Right? What`s your biggest concern with this executive order?

JANAI NELSON: My biggest concern is that this is an attempt to dismantle our entire civil rights infrastructure. Gone are the days where someone`s going to say out loud, I want to discriminate against you because you are, you know, black or a woman or a person who`s a member of the LGBTQ plus community. We don`t see smoking guns like that anymore. That doesn`t mean though that discrimination is gone. It still exists. When we see imbalances, when we see inequality, we have a duty to interrogate it.

So I`m worried that if this executive order is able to be enforced, which it absolutely shouldn`t, it is thoroughly unlawful, but if for some reason it does get enforced, it is going to undermine the entire civil rights infrastructure that this country has relied on to diversify the ranks of leadership with more women, with more people of color, with people with disabilities, with people from all different backgrounds, we will be an entirely different America, which is really what this Trump administration is after.

MAURICE DUBOIS: One final thought here. The executive orders framed disparate impact as being divisive and endangering equal opportunity more broadly. You hear the president talk about DEI in this way as well. What do you make of all that?

JANAI NELSON: Listen, this is just more of the lies and falsehoods that President Trump loves trafficking in. He uses words like equal opportunity, which come out of the civil rights movement, to weaponize those words against the very people they were intended to benefit, which is frankly all Americans. All Americans benefit from all of us having equal opportunity to achieve and to access opportunity, which makes this country better.

It`s the reason that we can even talk about America`s greatness. It`s because of civil rights laws and protections that remove the barriers that sideline so many for generations.

MAURICE DUBOIS: Okay. Janai Nelson, president of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, thanks so much for the insight tonight.

JANAI NELSON: Thank you, Maurice.

MAURICE DUBOIS: Now, here are three things to note tonight. The Trump administration has asked the Supreme Court to allow it to immediately enforce its policy against transgender individuals in the military, even while lower courts hear challenges from LGBTQ groups who say the policy violates the Constitution`s Equal Protection Clause. A baffling discovery three miles deep in the Pacific.

Researchers using remote cameras to explore the rusting hulk of the World War II aircraft carrier, U.S. Yorktown, found a Ford automobile parked in the ship`s hangar. No one can yet explain what the vehicle was doing on a ship that was on its way to the historic Battle of the Midway.

And your dog may be your best friend, but how does Fido stack up against everybody else in your life? Well, a new study of 700 dog owners published in the journal Scientific Reports finds that dogs score higher on the companionship scale than our closest relatives, our best friends, and even our romantic partners. No comment.

Coming up on CBS EVENING NEWS PLUS here tonight, we go in-depth on what happens when Mother Nature wipes out your home, but you still have to pay the mortgage.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

MAURICE DUBOIS: When a natural disaster strikes, it can create a financial storm for homeowners who`ve lost it all. In tonight`s In Depth, CBS` Dave Malkoff reports many are often left temporarily homeless and still obligated to pay their mortgage.

(Begin VT)

BETH BRIGHTMAN (Home Damaged By Hurricane Helene): Double pane glass doors still have water in them from the storm.

DAVE MALKOFF (voiceover): You can still see the flood damage six months after Hurricane Helene hit Beth and Alex Brightman`s home in Hudson on Florida`s west coast.

BETH BRIGHTMAN: Oh my God, this stuff that was in my china cabinet!

DAVE MALKOFF (voiceover): Since then, they`ve changed the message at their door.

BETH BRIGHTMAN: Let`s not stay home. It originally said let`s stay home because that`s all we wanted to do was stay here in our retirement home.

DAVE MALKOFF (voiceover): Flood insurance only covered damage to the structure and homeowner`s insurance doesn`t cover contents lost from flooding.

BETH BRIGHTMAN: If we had a hole in the roof and rain came in, then our belongings would have been covered through the homeowners.

DAVE MALKOFF (voiceover): So they`re using savings for repairs while living in a rental still with a $2,500 monthly mortgage.

BETH BRIGHTMAN: We still kind of live paycheck to paycheck.

DAVE MALKOFF (voiceover): About a month after Hurricanes Helene and Milton hit the southeast, nearly 60,000 homeowners fell behind on their mortgages. And there`s been a similar trend after the L.A. wildfires. Right now, 4,100 homeowners there are delinquent on their mortgage payments.

PAUL WILLEN (Economist): They understand that you have short-term cash flow issues.

DAVE MALKOFF (voiceover): Economist Paul Willen says historically, lenders have worked out arrangements with disaster victims.

PAUL WILLEN: The last thing they want is for a borrower to end up defaulting on a mortgage.

DAVE MALKOFF (voiceover): One option with your bank is forbearance, which gives you temporary pause on your mortgage payments.

PAUL WILLEN: It would basically give you a way of paying for stuff up front and freeing up cash flow.

DAVE MALKOFF (voiceover): It`s given the Breitmans relief from their house payments for six months.

BETH BRIGHTMAN: It`s been helpful, but then now it`s going to turn around and be a big bite.

DAVE MALKOFF (voiceover): That bite will be about $15,000, the total amount deferred, now coming due. And forbearance can also have long-term consequences for homeowners, affecting credit, ability to refinance, and home equity.

BETH BRIGHTMAN: This is the year to rebuild, recover, and then --

ALEX BRIGHTMAN (Home Damaged By Hurricane Helene): Go from there.

DAVE MALKOFF: Just get back to the day before the storm. That`s all you want.

BETH BRIGHTMAN: If they could go to September 25, 2024, that`d be nice.

DAVE MALKOFF (voiceover): If they could go back, they would have prepared differently, adding insurance and protecting their belongings before --

BETH BRIGHTMAN: Oh, my God.

DAVE MALKOFF: -- Helene arrived on their doorstep.

Dave Malkoff, CBS News, Hudson, Florida.

(End VT)

MAURICE DUBOIS: When we return, John Dickerson from Rome with tonight`s interview.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

MAURICE DUBOIS: Thousands continue to pay tribute to Pope Francis as he lies in state in St. Peter`s Basilica. John Dickerson is in Rome to cover Saturday`s funeral, and for tonight`s interview, he spoke with Father Matthew Berrios, who leads St. Patrick`s Catholic American Parish, and asked him about the legacy Francis leaves behind.

(Begin VT)

JOHN DICKERSON: Let`s talk about the moment you heard that Pope Francis had passed. Where were you and how did that news -- how did you receive that news?

FR. MATTHEW BERRIOS (St. Patrick`s Catholic American Parish In Rome): It must have been somewhere around 9 o`clock in the morning. I was having coffee in the living room, finished with morning prayer, and the Vice Rector, Fr. Fr. Greg Apparcel, sent me a text just very simply saying, the Holy Father died.

It was a little surreal, I suppose, and so I had to check the "New York Times" and a couple of other outlets just to see if that was in fact true, because living here, you hear all sorts of things. As a priest friend of mine said, Roman gossip is the best gossip. Sometimes it`s even true, so you have to double-check your sources.

But no, it was very shocking. We had expected it for a while. We didn`t expect that it would happen so suddenly.

JOHN DICKERSON: He was the pope for most of the time that you were -- I mean, for the time that you`ve been a priest, he`s mostly been your pope, yeah?

FR. MATTHEW BERRIOS: He has been pope for the majority of my time as a religious. I think I was only in seminary for maybe two or three years when he was elected, and so for most of my life as a Paulist, I`ve only known Francis.

JOHN DICKERSON: Do you see any evidence that Pope Francis brought people either back into the Catholic Church who had lapsed or people who were not religious but came through his more public persona?

FR. MATTHEW BERRIOS: I think, yes, absolutely. People were able to come back to the Church if they had felt alienated, precisely because he was willing to have the tough conversations with peoples and person groups that maybe many people in the Church had ignored or outright disparaged. There was nothing to be afraid of in engaging and welcoming and trying to have a certain accoglienza towards the rest of the world. Even those who aren`t religious felt a certain warmth and friendliness and fondness towards him.

JOHN DICKERSON: As I think about people joining the Church, what was -- what was your -- why did you join the priesthood?

FR. MATTHEW BERRIOS: Well, the simple answer is because I was called, but what the call feels like is a little nebulous. In some ways, it`s like an attraction. It`s like gravity. It`s almost like falling in love with the call of a certain style of life and a certain way of prayer and a certain way of being.

JOHN DICKERSON: What does the Catholic Church need to do to recruit more priests?

FR. MATTHEW BERRIOS: Well, what makes priesthood attractive to young people, I think, is those who are currently priests living their priesthood joyfully because that`s a beautiful and attractive thing when you find someone who`s so fallen in love with the life that they`ve been called to that it flowers and becomes a place of grace and inspiration for others around them.

JOHN DICKERSON: We live in a time where a lot of people in different countries all over the world believe in a different thing. Latest and loudest, largest, biggest, how does that create an appetite for the case for humility that you just made or does it make it more difficult to preach humility in a world where if it`s not flashy and gold-plated, it doesn`t count?

FR. MATTHEW BERRIOS: The faith becomes a sign of contradiction in that way, and it`s not necessarily something bad because the Church at one level will always be countercultural. No matter what the current trends of culture might be, the Church will always have something to proclaim, and if we live it authentically, it`ll be something attractive. It`ll be something beautiful because it`s living. It comes from our groundedness in God, to his life, and love itself.

JOHN DICKERSON: Living it authentically sounds like your description of Pope Francis.

FR. MATTHEW BERRIOS: Absolutely.

(End VT)

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

MAURICE DUBOIS: Finally tonight, something most of us don`t see every day, a real live bison jam. On a recent trip to Yellowstone National Park, tourist Cindy Shaffer captured this unique moment. A herd of these majestic beasts stopping traffic for nearly 20 minutes as they slowly cross the road.

The park service says there are some 5,400 bison roaming Yellowstone. The fact that we`re lucky enough to steal even a glance of the bison in the wild today is a miracle in itself. In the 1800s, it`s estimated as many as 60 million of them populated the plains and west.

But as the American frontier expanded, the bison population declined due to hunting and disease. Only a few hundred remained before the turn of the century. Ambitious conservation efforts, though, have allowed the bison to make a comeback. Today, the Interior Department supports herds of some 11,000 bison across 12 states. Restoring a piece of American history for future generations.

And that is tonight`s CBS EVENING NEWS PLUS. Thanks for joining us. I`m Maurice DuBois.

Have a good night.

urn:contentItem:6CFV-68X1-JBSP-11VJ-00000-00Research on Physics Discussed by a Researcher at University of Calgary (Comparison of Perimeter Delineation Methods for Remote Sensing Fire Spot Data in Near/Ultra-Real-Time Applications)2024-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisPHYSICSResearch on Physics Discussed by a Researcher at University of Calgary (Comparison of Perimeter Delineation Methods for Remote Sensing Fire Spot Data in Near/Ultra-Real-Time Applications)


2024 JUL 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- Data detailed on physics have been presented. According to news reporting from Calgary, Canada, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires cause extensive damage to ecosystems, biodiversity, and human property, posing significant challenges for emergency response and resource management."


Financial supporters for this research include Nserc Discovery Grant; Alberta Innovates ‘nserc Alliance-alberta Innovates Advance Program' Grant.
The news editors obtained a quote from the research from University of Calgary: "The accurate and timely delineation of forest fire perimeters is crucial for mitigating these impacts. In this study, methods for delineating forest fire perimeters using near-real-time (NRT) remote sensing data are evaluated. Specifically, the performance of various algorithms-buffer, concave, convex, and combination methods-using VIIRS and MODIS datasets is assessed. It was found that increasing concave a values improves the matching percentage with reference areas but also increases the commission error (CE), indicating overestimation. The results demonstrate that combination methods generally achieve higher matching percentages, but also higher CEs. These findings highlight the trade-off between improved perimeter accuracy and the risk of overestimation."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The insights gained are significant for optimizing sensor data alignment techniques, thereby enhancing rapid response, resource allocation, and evacuation planning in fire management. This research is the first to employ multiple algorithms in both individual and synergistic approaches with NRT or ultra-real-time (URT) active fire data, providing a critical foundation for future studies aimed at improving the accuracy and timeliness of forest fire perimeter assessments. Such advancements are essential for effective disaster management and mitigation strategies."
For more information on this research see: Comparison of Perimeter Delineation Methods for Remote Sensing Fire Spot Data in Near/Ultra-Real-Time Applications. Fire, 2024,7(7). (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire7070226.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Hanif Bhuian, Department of Geomatics Engineering, University of Calgary, 2500 University Drive NW, Calgary, AB T2N 1N4, Canada. Additional authors for this research include Hatef Dastour, Mohammad Razu Ahmed, Quazi K. Hassan.

urn:contentItem:6DMW-TD01-DY7R-R1S4-00000-00Researcher at D. Serikbayev East Kazakhstan Technical University Targets Remote Sensing (Spatial analysis and mapping of potential wildfires from Landsat satellite data)2024-12-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisREMOTE SENSINGResearcher at D. Serikbayev East Kazakhstan Technical University Targets Remote Sensing (Spatial analysis and mapping of potential wildfires from Landsat satellite data)


2024 DEC 13 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Data detailed on remote sensing have been presented. According to news originating from D. Serikbayev East Kazakhstan Technical University by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "In 2023 there was a severe forest fire on the territory of the Semipalatinsk Forest. More than 60 thousand ha were burned."


Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from D. Serikbayev East Kazakhstan Technical University: "This resulted in high environmental costs, destroying trees, real estate, recreational and even human lives. One of the most pressing issues was the determination of the origin and spread of forest fires. In such cases, remote sensing data is a spatial and temporal measure to obtain fast and accurate data to prevent the further spread of the fire and to neutralize this natural disaster. Using such geospatial information, it is possible to prioritize preventive measures to reduce the risk of forest fires and identify mitigating factors to increase the likelihood of immediate fire suppression in threatened areas. This work proposes to assess the fire potential and to determine the hazard potential. This is done by analyzing and mapping the area of the fire that has occurred. The mapping of the fire potential was approached from a remote sensing point of view by estimating and mapping the total vegetation cover using Landsat-8-9 OLI/TIRS DATA and the geographic information systems QGIS, SAGAGIS. A morphometric, spatial analysis of conditions was also conducted, taking into account many factors affecting fire potential-land exposure, aspect, wind direction, fire statistics, population density, climatic characteristics, etc. As a result, an attempt was made to create indices RBR, RdNBR, dNDVI, dGNDI, GEMI and BAI, which could be the basis for the determination of fire potential. These indices are based on the type of tree, the vegetation and the topographic features."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These characteristics make it possible, after the classification of the Landsat images, to evaluate the reliability of the information obtained by determining the area of the fire through the Object Based Image Analysis segmentation method and by assessing the accuracy of the detected data. The index values identified were consistent with reliable information for identifying fire locations and monitoring estimated fire risk. They could be used to map fire potential from regional to local scales."
For more information on this research see: Spatial analysis and mapping of potential wildfires from Landsat satellite data. InterCarto. InterGIS, 2024,30(1). (InterCarto. InterGIS - http://intercarto.msu.ru). The publisher for InterCarto. InterGIS is LLC Kartfond.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.35595/2414-9179-2024-1-30-476-490.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Elibek Asangaliyev, D. Serikbayev East Kazakhstan Technical University, School of Earth Sciences, 69, Protozanova str., Ust-Kamenogorsk, 070004, Kazakhstan, . Additional authors for this research include Baitak Apshikur, Sergey Lutay, Zhanna Assylkhanova.

urn:contentItem:6DH5-BGT1-JC11-13CG-00000-00Air Quality, Atmosphere & Health Journal Issues Research Articles in October 2024 Special Issue Entitled HARMO21 - Harmonisation Within Atmospheric Dispersion Modelling for Regulatory Purposes2024-11-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisAir Quality, Atmosphere & Health Journal Issues Research Articles in October 2024 Special Issue Entitled HARMO21 - Harmonisation Within Atmospheric Dispersion Modelling for Regulatory PurposesTargeted News ServiceBERLIN, Germany

Air Quality, Atmosphere and Health, a peer-reviewed journal that addresses topics such as acid precipitation, air quality monitoring and management, air pollution climatology, atmospheric impact assessment, forest-fire emissions, greenhouse gases, health and ecological effects and clean air technology, published research articles on the following topics in its October 2024 special issue (Vol. 17, Issue 10) entitled HARMO21 - Harmonisation Within Atmospheric Dispersion Modelling for Regulatory Purposes:

* A satellite-based, near real-time, street-level resolution air pollutants monitoring system using machine learning for personalised skin health applications

* AIRQ HARMO21 special issue--PREFACE

* Analyses of industrial air pollution and long-term health risk using different dispersion models and WRF physics parameters

* Atmospheric deposition studies of microplastics in Central Germany

* Characteristics and ozone formation potentials of volatile organic compounds in a heavy industrial urban agglomeration of Northeast China

* Comparing machine learning and inverse modeling approaches for the source term estimation

* Does urban particulate matter hinder COVID-19 transmission rate?

* Impact assessment of IMO's sulfur content limits: a case study at latin America's largest grain port

* Investigation of emissions from passenger flights Denizli Cardak Airport, Turkiye

* Lagrangian plume rise and dispersion modelling of the large-scale lithium-ion battery fire in Morris, USA, 2021

* Modeling of carbonaceous aerosols for air pollution health impact studies in Europe

* Ozone variability, its formation potential and crops losses in the himalayan foothills

* OzoneNet:A spatiotemporal information attention encoder model for ozone concentrations prediction with multi-source data

* Pseudo-total metal loads in dusts and soils of the steel city and coal capital of India: source apportionment and assessment of human health and ecological risks

* Reduction of simulation times by application of a kernel method in a high-resolution Lagrangian particle dispersion model

* Revisiting dry deposition modelling of particulate matter on vegetation at the microscale

* Setting up a CFD model to evaluate the impact of green infrastructures on local air quality

* Spatial model for daily air quality high resolution estimation

* The association between short-term ozone exposure and fasting blood glucose levels in non-diabetic adults was more obvious in rural residents: the evidence from a typical "urban-rural dual structure" province in southwestern China

* Understanding the spatiotemporal distribution of aerosols and their association with natural and anthropogenic factors over Saudi Arabia using multi-sensor remote sensing data

The October 2024 edition of the Air Quality, Atmosphere & Health Journal can be viewed at https://link.springer.com/journal/11869/volumes-and-issues/17-10. The journal is published by Springer Nature.

[Category: Environment]

urn:contentItem:6DH5-8S91-JC3D-Y2NR-00000-00Rocket Lab completes two launches in under 24 hours2024-11-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisRocket Lab completes two launches in under 24 hoursSydney, Australia (SPX) Nov 26, 2024

Rocket Lab USA, Inc. (Nasdaq: RKLB) has achieved a significant milestone, completing its 56th Electron mission and deploying five satellites for French Internet-of-Things (IoT) constellation operator Kineis.

The mission, titled "Ice AIS Baby," launched from Rocket Lab's Launch Complex 1 in Mahia, New Zealand, at 4:55 pm on November 25 NZDT (03:55 UTC). The satellites were deployed into a 643 km low Earth orbit, marking Rocket Lab's 14th mission of 2024 and 56th mission overall.

This operation pushed the company's total deployed satellites to 203, affirming Electron's status as a leader among small launch vehicles. Notably, this launch occurred just 21 hours and 55 minutes after a successful mission from Launch Complex 2 in Virginia, setting a new company record for the shortest turnaround between launches.

Rocket Lab founder and CEO Sir Peter Beck highlighted the achievement: "Two successful launches less than 24 hours apart from pads in different hemispheres. That's unprecedented capability in the small launch market and one we're immensely proud to deliver at Rocket Lab. Customers like Kineis are unlocking the potential of space and we're excited to give them the keys to do so with frequent, dedicated, and reliable small launch opportunities."

Kineis CEO Alexandre Tisserant praised the mission's precision: "The Kineis teams have once again demonstrated their technical capabilities as satellite operators by taking control of these five new satellites at a sustained launch rate. This achievement would not have been possible without Rocket Lab's Electron precision in placing our satellites in their planned positions.

"With 15 Kineis satellites now in orbit, we're one step closer to the full deployment of our dedicated IoT constellation for transmitting data in near-real time, anywhere on the globe. Congratulations to all our teams, who are doing an incredible job - and, let's not forget, a European first! We're equally enthusiastic about our second mission, AIS. In a rapidly consolidating market, Kineis is establishing itself as a sovereign European player, combining technological expertise and strategic independence. With our new AIS offering, we provide maritime players with enhanced visibility over their fleets, while ensuring higher data reliability."

This was the third of five dedicated Electron launches for Kineis, supported by private and public investments, including backing from the French government's space agency CNES and CLS (Collecte Localisation Satellites). The Kineis constellation aims to enable global IoT connectivity by offering near-real-time data transmission with low energy consumption. Applications of the constellation include monitoring water resources, forest fire detection, tracking transport and logistics, and managing infrastructure and energy networks in remote locations.

urn:contentItem:6F6T-T513-RW38-33SY-00000-00Spongy moths expected to be moderate across region2025-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSSpongy moths expected to be moderate across regionJessica DelfinoThe Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

Spongy moth caterpillars are wreaking havoc in wooded lots and forests across Pennsylvania.

But the good news is populations appear to be dwindling.

It’s the caterpillar stage of the spongy moths, also known to entomologists and lepidopterists as “Lymantria dispar” and formerly as gypsy moths, which can cause the most harm to local trees. To combat this, the state Department of Conservation and Natural Resources is engaging in a concerted effort to inform wooded lot and forested land owners how to protect their property from the invasive species.

Currently, the moths are doing the most damage in Pike and Monroe counties, as well as in southern Wayne County. Last year across Lackawanna and Luzerne counties, foresters observed light activity through forests and wooded lots.

Service forester for the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources Julian Maza shows a cellphone application that is used to track spongy moth egg masses in any location near the Elmhurst Reservoir Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. The department does surveys when the leaves are off the trees in the fall and winter, for easier visibilty. (SEAN MCKEAG / STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)

Service forester for the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources Julian Maza uses binoculars to look for egg masses that remain from spongy moths near the Elmhurst Reservoir Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. (SEAN MCKEAG / STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)

Department of Conservation and Natural Resources resource forester Nate Cunfer and service forester Julian Maza look for egg masses that remain from spongy moths near the Elmhurst Reservoir Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. (SEAN MCKEAG / STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)

Service forester for the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources Julian Maza looks for spongy moth egg masses using his cellphone camera with his binoculars, with the help of Resource forester Nate Cunfer, near the Elmhurst Reservoir Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. (SEAN MCKEAG / STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)

Service forester for the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources Julian Maza looks for spongy moth egg masses near the Elmhurst Reservoir Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. (SEAN MCKEAG / STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)

Off color blemishes are left on the branches of a Northern Red Oak tree from spongy moth egg masses that occupied the tree from recent year’s past. (SEAN MCKEAG / STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)

In a wooded area near the Elmhurst Reservoir spongy moth egg masses can populate the tops of Northern Red Oak, Red Maple and Sugar Maple trees.

Service forester for the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources Julian Maza looks for spongy moth egg masses in a wooded area near the Elmurst Reservoir Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. (SEAN MCKEAG / STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)

Service forester for the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources Julian Maza looks through binoculars for spongy moth egg masses on the tops of trees in a wooded area near the Elmurst Reservoir Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. Assisting Maza is the department’s resource forester Nate Cunfer. (SEAN MCKEAG / STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)

Show Caption

1 of 9

Service forester for the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources Julian Maza shows a cellphone application that is used to track spongy moth egg masses in any location near the Elmhurst Reservoir Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. The department does surveys when the leaves are off the trees in the fall and winter, for easier visibilty. (SEAN MCKEAG / STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)

Expand

Julian Maza, a service forester, Bureau of Forestry for the Pinchot Forest District, said that overall a downward trend in the populations of spongy moths across Pennsylvania is being observed.

“DCNR will spray 75,000 acres statewide this year, and then last year we sprayed 227,000 acres,” Maza explained, adding the variation in spongy moth populations is typical over years. “They kind of come in fluctuations, and then they just hit a population collapse.”

In other words, after a while, they make like a tree and leave.

A variety of trees are vulnerable to damage, said Tim Latz, assistant district forester in the Bureau of Forestry for the Pinchot State Forest.

“You have several species of trees that are highly attractive to spongy moths, so all oak species, most maple, red maple, sugar maple, and almost every species of deciduous trees,” said Latz. “They don’t like pine that much, so if your forest is mostly pine, you should be OK.”

Other trees that spongy moths infest include apple, alder, aspen, basswood, birch, hemlock, spruce, tamarack (larch), willows and witch hazel, per DCNR’s press release. Pine is included on the list.

Latz said prior year infestations can be an indicator of what’s to come for the next year. He said heavy infestation, year over year, is what can lead to tree death.

“Typically, you need a heavy infestation for two years to really start to see mortality,” Latz explained. “So, for Lackawanna, Susquehanna, Wayne, Luzerne, Wyoming, which is to the northeast of where the Pinchot is, for those counties, right now, we’re checking for egg masses.”

Latz said the moths are currently overwintering in an egg stage, and as of now, foresters are “not really finding high populations of egg masses in those counties.”

“So, we expect, at worst, probably moderate, and so I would say it’s going to be more or less nuisance levels in those moderate areas,” he said. Areas that are low or moderate the previous year are probably going to be moderate or high the following year, he added.

The sprays used to combat spongy moths, per the press release, include Bacillus thuringiensis kurstaki (Btk) and Tebufenozide (Mimic), which they describe as “safe and effective products” to suppress infestations. The release also shared information for property owners to find resources to protect their trees, including a list of aerial applicators and expert foresters in each county.

Maza explained that foresters are available to answer questions about the moths and other questions involving their tree population, and can consult on how and if landowners should treat their property for spongy moths and other afflictions. In Lackawanna County, Maza recommended landowners call the Bureau of Forestry for the Pinchot State Forest’s office in South Abington Twp. at 570-945-7133 for help. He also pointed property owners to the spongy moth page on the DCNR’s website, where he said maps of activity and other resources can be found.

Jeff King, founder and president of the Pest Rangers, headquartered in Hanover Twp., said he has been called to spray for spongy moths at the request of homeowners who didn’t fall into Pennsylvania’s designated spray areas, leaving them to fend for themselves in terms of cost.

“People have large oak trees that want to save their trees,” he said. “They’ll do a number on old oaks.”

The service isn’t cheap.

“We’ve seen them go from the low end of $695 up to $2,200, and it’s really because we’re doing it from the ground,” he said, explaining that treatment delivered by helicopter covers terrain more efficiently and uses less material.

He explained that in years past, some homes opted to skip treatment, which didn’t fare well for them.

“It looked like a forest fire went through,” he said.

He advised neighborhoods — for example, homeowner associations — to consider pitching in a small amount per house, explaining that homeowners who do it that way can ultimately save money.

“People won’t pay for the treatment, and then they’ll end up paying $1,200 to get the tree taken down,” King said.

Those who are not willing or able to invest in the spray have other options, such as “mechanical removal” of eggs, which is best for yards with a sparse tree population. Egg masses may be hiding in piles of old wood, building materials and dead branches. They can be scraped into a container, sealed and then disposed of. Wrapping burlap around the trunks of trees and then disposing of the larvae by scraping them into soapy water will kill them, per the DNCR’s spongy moth page.

urn:contentItem:6FHJ-42R3-RRMD-M3P0-00000-00The Undecim: April Fools!2025-04-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1The Undecim: April Fools!

BREAKING NEWS: GOUCHER COLLEGE LEASES OUT ENTIRE CAMPUS

Goucher College's Towson Campus starts leasing almost every inch of campus to corporations for 99 or 50 years each.

IKEA rents out horse stables to "test new and old products." Beatrice Moody '25, Goucher's greatest equestrian champion, is "outraged and flabbergasted."

Chick-fil-a leases the student market, promising to use profits to donate to anti-gay groups. Brian Kal '26 says he's "excited to see the fried chicken be upgraded."

Starbucks Coffee rents Mary Fisher dining hall, promising to create a "family not union" attitude for the entire campus. Students are concerned that there will no longer be a more nutritious food option, but are swayed by chai caramel lattes with extra cream.

Forever 21 leases Stimson, following the recent closure of their Towson store. Faculty voice their confusion.

Welsh Hall has been leased to a nursing home, Eagle Ridge At Grand Valley. Eagle Ridge will give more opportunities for overworking as student nurses in the newly created nursing program. Our reporter Xam Ykztinvar found this assisted senior living program on the Nursing Homes To Avoid list of AssistedSeniorliving.net and was happy to hear Goucher is partnering with the worst of the worst.

The Athenaeum has been sold to Nazi group Hawk White, as they wish to burn more books. All pornographic material will be burned, even as Steve Grate, President of Hawk White, was found yesterday sleeping with two underaged boys. This is a big win for the portion of the student body who wishes there to be less complicated lies thrown in their faces by professors. They will now be told the truth about how many genders there are.

Generik Shell Inc. has purchased Julia Rogers. No one knows exactly who is behind this company.

Sheppard Pratt takes over Goucher's Psychology Annex only to find it empty, not filled with crazed monkeys as expected. Crazy Reporter Ykztinvar Xam, requested comments from Psychology students, only to find he had been duped into giving them free therapy. The Neuroscience faculty expressed anger at the neighboring department having the most successful major on campus.

DuPont Chemical Company has gained control of Hoffberger as they aim to study how to maximize harm to the environment as partners in the new Masters of Environmental Destruction and Biological Warfare. 4+1 programs will be offered with the old online hybrid anti-corporate Justice of Science major.

Worker owned construction company McCarthy will be taking the land where Myerhoff stands and building their new headquarters. McCarthy representative Janet Wilty said they "were upset to learn Goucher had only given them 38 years, instead of the 50 years plus option to buy that Whiting and Turner has."

In a surprise turn, the Student Recreations Center is exempted from leasing. When asked why, administrators told reporters the sports teams had the greatest puppy eyes ever imagined. New athletics director Kathlin Helstcher denies this, and says, "they held their place as the aspect of the institution that brings the most value."

Goucher faces a lawsuit, having double-booked the full time leases with a Republican Youth training camp over the whole campus this summer. Bradly Yapper '27 is "severely disappointed in Goucher" as he was set to work as an assistant manager for the camp. Goucher paid 3 million for the rights to host this event. The Goucher Dean of Students claims, "this would have brought much needed publicity and diversity of thought to this campus." Lawyers' fees are estimated to be over 8 million dollars.

1960s GOUCHER STUDENTS DISCOVERED IN DORSEY NUCLEAR SHELTER

69 Gophers, students, faculty, and staff were discovered forgotten in the basement fallout shelter under Dorsey Center, after the administration opened it to try to sell it. They claim they went for a tour, but got locked in and were forgotten about for the last sixty years. Lisa Weary '64 was outraged to learn that "gays and communists have taken over the school." Conversely, Pamela Bahgly '65 was excited to learn more about safe sex in modern times, as the last discussion of the sort she attended was the Goucher Reverend's "sex sermon."

Angela Jenrick '63 said she is "glad to see the progress made on racially integrating the campus, even as [she] disapproves of the decision to admit men." Facilities Management Services claim "they were unaware of the bunker" despite cleaning records showing they sent services in, and it being a primary location in the Emergency Action Plan.

All sixty of the bunker group signed a petition to bring back the Tone Committee as they desire more control and sensibility over Goucher's fashion. Grace Pembory '67 is "dismayed by the Student Government Association and desires a return to House culture and rule."

Goucher's Radio club discovers that the Goucher radio station has actually been on the air for the last twenty years thanks to 1960's Gophers who listened to radio while stuck.

Students inspired by conversations with the 1960 crew argue that the Board of Overseers should return, as they claim Goucher is not corporate enough. The Board of Overseers was an organization created by President Kraushaar to help local business owners appreciate Goucher by acting in a purely advisory role. This worked as significant donations came in, but the promise of not allowing them on the Board of Trustees was broken, as the two boards eventually merged.

Leading this effort is Frank Ly, class of 2026, who argues, "Goucher students don't pay enough in tuition, Goucher needs to take the future on with a proper corporate attitude." He also criticized Quindecim reporter Jimy Kuhn, saying "the Quindecim needs to not let hippie lunatics who want peace, love, and plants publish their work."

Goucher President Jack Trickle responded by saying "Goucher will never sell out its values of family and community, which is why we are inviting so many helpful groups on campus-so they can create more opportunities for our community."

NEW HIGH SPEED RAIL SYSTEM SHOCKS STUDENTS

Goucher expects students will need to take transit between the two campuses in a decade, so is starting on plans to build a High Speed Rail between the campuses in collaboration with Brightline.

Quindecim Transit expert Olim Namrevlis '27 voices concerns over how fast this will be built and worries about all the car owners on campus. "With this rapid three month plan, the community will not have the time to set schedules around this. The richest among us will pay the brunt, and that is not okay." He couched his statement: "Brightline thinks through the impacts of their projects and takes absolutely no government money, so I trust them to slow down the project and think about the bottom line for the college."

Vincent Grahmon '28 says, "With college students using trains, the death rate of this development will be too low. The system should divert itself to pass by an elementary school." Bunker students started teaching games and songs from their time transiting between campuses to the modern students who will soon face a similar commute.

GENETICALLY MODIFIED SQUIRRELS BREACH CONTAINMENT

B.A.S.S. squirrels escape from the trap set in the bunker and wreak havoc on campus. Bald Assed Squirrels Syndrome, first reported in the 1995 Undecim by C.I. Meyers are genetically altered squirrels which mysteriously disappeared in 1996. They are responsible for incidents such as The Wall forest fire, Max's Great Fall, and for stealing a couch cushion from the library. Professor Christopher Torres was seen being chased down Van Meter Highway. Students are warned to steer clear. More mayhem is expected as President Trickle refuses to respond. Administrators who spoke on the condition of anonymity, claim everyone is afraid, and this is the true reason for leasing everything away-to escape it all.

GOUCHER COLLEGE RETURNS TO WOMEN-ONLY ROOTS

Following the bunker incident, protests over Goucher being Co-Educational re-erupt, pushing the board of trustees to return Goucher's status as a Women's College. Days into the change, students who responded to the Goucher Poll say they noticed no changes. Separately, the Goucher Poll announced it is too successful to remain named after this shitty institution and is changing its name to "Lirpa Sloof Polling Corporation" and is looking to scale up. Documents recently uncovered with help from insiders Nina K. and Bill H. (names redacted for privacy) show that the Poll owns Generik Shell inc.

After a week of Chaos, the Committee on Bunker People unanimously decides to force 1960s era Gophers back under Dorsey. Will Goucher force visiting Alumni from Alumni Weekend to join them? What will happen to them? Please petition Goucher to let me in the old nuclear bunker so we can all find out.

All above pieces by Xam Ykztinvar, '28.

DOES KENT "FREAK IT?" AND IF SO, HOW?

To freak, or not to freak. This is the timeless question we must ask of the lords of our institutions. The action of freaking carries great and complex meaning. It is not always good, it is not always bad. It is not inherently sexual. Freaking is freaking; and a freak is a freak. We must open our minds as we ponder this, in relation to our president Kent Devereaux. A great man, and a puzzle at times. The question of whether Kent freaks seems impossible to answer at first thought. After all, he seems quite the private man, how could we successfully speculate on his freaky nature or lack thereof? Well, there are some notable sciences that we can look to for answers. By respecting these pillars of thought, perhaps we can answer this question. And depending on the answer, ponder greater details of the noble Kent Devereaux.

My first piece of evidence was intended to be a deep analysis of Kent Devereaux's birth sign, and the implications of it. Unfortunately, despite searching his Wikipedia page, I couldn't find his birthday.

My second piece of evidence is his incredible fashion style. There is often great intention in the way a person presents. And if we analyze Kent's fashion, we find powerful details. A clean cut style, composed and practiced. And that hat, what a magnificent hat. It speaks of charm, wit, and a coolness to pierce through the crowd. That is the hat of a man who could freak.

Now that we have thoroughly and conclusively proven the freaky nature of Kent Devereaux, we must elaborate on the freaky nature that he almost certainly possesses. What mystifyingly magical activities occur in Kent's house after the sun sets? What fascinatingly fantastic feats have been performed? Perchance. We can attempt to guess from what we already know of him. He has great musical experience, so perhaps he plays the fiddle to enchant all his house guests. There is also his aforementioned hat. Perhaps late at night, he puts the hat back on, spins it around once or twice, and summons the "dawg in him" to unleash furious passion out onto the world. He is often withdrawn from the public eye, but is that because he fears the spotlight, or because he simply doesn't need one to stun his audience? 

Kent Devereaux is certainly a mystery, one that may never be solved while I still walk this campus. However, some things we are sure about in regard to him. We know he has an awesome hat. And we also know he freaks it. In these dark times, let these two facts be of solace to you, to guide you past murky rivers and eerie lands, into a comfortable bed of safety and understanding.

By Dragonslayer Willow, '26

A Galloping Success: Goucher's Jousting Team Makes It to Playoffs

Archibald Fletcher, '26, takes a victory lap after winning the joust of war.

In a tumultuous match, Goucher's jousting team beat Salisbury to advance to the playoff round. The team presented a remarkable display of athleticism, performing particularly well in the ring joust. "Salisbury had copper rings instead of brass. Their athletics budget must be a lot higher than ours," observed Bartholomew Gardiner, '26. Gardiner represented his team during the ring portion, successfully hooking the ring on his lance during all three passes and winning the round 3-2.

Emotions ran high during the joust of war. After a hotly competitive training season, Archibald Fletcher, '25, was selected to represent Goucher for this portion of the tournament. During the first pass, Fletcher inadvertently formed a barricade with his lance, breaking it in half. Since this is not considered a legal break, the jousters had to reset and Fletcher's lance was replaced. After this incident, Fletcher showed sheer force and skill during every pass. He unhorsed his opponent twice, before shattering his lance on his opponent's chest plate to win the joust.

Goucher's equestrian stables worked alongside the jousting team to select the most capable horses. Following careful deliberation, Bucephalus and Nosewise were chosen to join the athletes for the tournament. Their specialized training involved subjecting the horses to random bugle fanfare to ensure they didn't startle during the joust. "Percival was a strong candidate, but due to frequent biting incidents, he didn't make the cut," explained the stable manager.

Goucher's stunning victory was met with numerous "Huzzah!"s from the crowd. The team is set to advance to the regional playoffs, where they will face York College first. "I'm very proud of my team this season," Fletcher commented. "I hope we win regionals because the prize turkey sounds really delicious."

By Stella Rose '26

"A MINECRAFT MOVIE" IS PEAK CINEMA

The title says it all. There has never been a movie as great as Warner Bros' "A Minecraft Movie", released Friday, April 4th. Words can't describe the 1 hour, 34 minutes, and 34 seconds long masterpiece the world has the honor of watching. But for those of you unable to see it for yourselves, I guess I'll have to take up the monumental task of transcribing such perfect art.

Where to start? I love exposition, and if you love it too, you're in luck. Almost every second of this movie's runtime is spent narrating what's on screen-and it's amazing! We're force fed information because the directors rightfully know audiences can't understand what's going on in their movie.

The writing is just impeccable, and the humor exquisite. Stellar lines like "Two big buffalos like us out there, in the wild, wearing unisex turquoise blazers. Oh man, that's gonna cause a commotion" had the entire theater guffawing. We also get sentimental moments such as people sharing incredibly personal details of their life unprompted, so that the camera can pan to one of our main characters tilting their head in confusion. So much character depth! So hilarious!

I was on the edge of my seat the entire movie with its incredible pacing and well-earned tension. I loved each and every one of the 25 minutes it takes for the characters to reach the new Minecraft universe. The totally new and steller isekai plotline is a treat to watch!

Of course, I can't forget about the breathtaking visuals. It was a great choice to place real actors in a hyper realistic CGI setting. It puts an exciting spin on the boring normal Minecraft style. Creepers with fur uplift the movie to even greater heights!

"A Minecraft Movie" is a must-watch for the whole family. It's a testament to great cinema that you'll be able to meme it for years after its box-office breaking release. Don't miss out on this historical moment!

By Jaiden Johnson '27

urn:contentItem:6F32-FRW3-S0CS-Y33P-00000-00Rocket Lab Launches Next Batch of Satellites for Kinéis Constellation2025-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisRocket Lab Launches Next Batch of Satellites for Kinéis ConstellationThe mission was the fourth mission in a five-launch deal with Kinéis to deploy the French company's entire internet-of-things constellationMAHIA, New Zealand

Rocket Lab USA, Inc. (Nasdaq: RKLB) ("Rocket Lab" or "the Company"), a global leader in launch services and space systems, today successfully launched its 59th Electron mission, deploying five satellites to Low Earth Orbit for French Internet-of-Things (IoT) constellation operator Kinéis.

This press release features multimedia. View the full release here: https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20250208666499/en/

Rocket Lab's Electron launch vehicle lifts-off from Launch Complex 1 carrying five satellites for French constellation operator Kinéis. (Photo: Business Wire)

The "IOT 4 You and Me" mission lifted-off from Rocket Lab Launch Complex 1 in Mahia, New Zealand at 9:43 am NZDT on 9 February (20:43 UTC), successfully deploying five satellites to a 647 km low Earth orbit. The mission was Rocket Lab's first Electron launch of 2025, fourth launch for Kinéis to date, and 59th Electron launch overall.

Rocket Lab founder and CEO Sir Peter Beck said: "That's four launches done and one still to go for Kinéis, then we'll have deployed their entire constellation in less than a year. It's not uncommon for constellation operators to wait longer than that for their first launch, let alone have a full constellation deployed and operating. Once again Electron has shown its strength as a pinpoint accurate constellation launcher that lets customers tailor missions and schedules to their needs."

Kinéis CTO Michel Sarthou said: "Producing 25 nanosatellites and launching them into orbit in just eight months is an unprecedented feat-and above all, a remarkable challenge! With this fourth and penultimate launch, Kinéis moves one step closer to its ambitious goal: delivering global IoT coverage through a complete constellation of 25 nanosatellites. This milestone showcases the expertise and determination of our teams and partners like Rocket Lab. We are deeply grateful for the unwavering support and commitment we have received since Kinéis was founded."

The Kinéis constellation is designed to make it possible to connect and locate any connected object anywhere in the world, enabling data transmission to users in near-real time, at low bit rates and with very low energy consumption. By enabling internet connection to the Earth's most remote locations, Kinéis constellation can support forest fire detection, water resource management, infrastructure and energy network monitoring, transport and logistics tracking, and much more.

The launch date for the fifth Kinéis launch in this series of missions will be announced in the coming weeks.

The next Electron launch is scheduled for lift-off in February, with the specific launch window and customer details to be announced in the coming days.

Launch images: https://www.flickr.com/photos/rocketlab/albums/72177720323462623

Launch webcast: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Al5hWmjoxQ

+ About Rocket Lab

Founded in 2006, Rocket Lab is an end-to-end space company with an established track record of mission success. We deliver reliable launch services, satellite manufacture, spacecraft components, and on-orbit management solutions that make it faster, easier, and more affordable to access space. Headquartered in Long Beach, California, Rocket Lab designs and manufactures the Electron small orbital launch vehicle, a family of flight-proven spacecraft, and the Company is developing the large Neutron launch vehicle for constellation deployment. Since its first orbital launch in January 2018, Rocket Lab's Electron launch vehicle has become the second most frequently launched U.S. rocket annually and has delivered more than 200 satellites to orbit for private and public sector organizations, enabling operations in national security, scientific research, space debris mitigation, Earth observation, climate monitoring, and communications. Rocket Lab's Photon spacecraft platform has been selected to support NASA missions to the Moon and Mars, as well as the first private commercial mission to Venus. Rocket Lab has three launch pads at two launch sites, including two launch pads at a private orbital launch site located in New Zealand and a third launch pad in Virginia. To learn more, visit www.rocketlabusa.com .

urn:contentItem:6BWB-3M61-JBSN-1005-00000-00Earth Foundries to Upcycle More Than Forest Fire Waste2024-04-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisEarth Foundries to Upcycle More Than Forest Fire Wasteby Huzair Latif

Earth Foundries Inc., an environmental waste upcycling company, has been carving out market share in California, and co-founders Dede and Roger Smullen plan to increase the company's scale and service offerings in the next 5 years. They are open to managing such growth with a partial investor, Roger Smullen said.Saratoga, Calif.-based Earth Foundries upcycles forest waste into carbon negative products such as biochar and green energy to combat help wildfires and global warming in California. The company's main clients include the state government and some private companies who have a stake in wildfire damage.

Founded in 2021, the company is still getting on its feet, but already has projects that will contribute to its aggressive growth, Smullen said.Business at a Glance8 employees (full-time and part-time)Doubled revenue from 2022 to 2023Profitable in 2023400 acres treated since 202110,000 tons of forest waste upcycledOver 600 tons of biochar createdSmullen is looking to expand the company's scale by buying another pyrolysis machine, the technology that allows for the creation of the biochar through carbon sequestration, by expanding into upcycling agricultural waste and by creating a product service management structure called an Incident Command System (ICS) so the company can deploy its services where they are needed most after a wildfire has ravaged parts of the Californian landscape. The company's ideal investor would be able to provide capital in order to fund such growth plans in the coming years.The move into agricultural waste would help remove the seasonality of the business as forest waste and wildfire remediation is primarily done in the summer and spring, while agricultural waste is primarily cleaned in the fall and winter, after a harvest.The company's main competitors in the region are companies that pileburn the wood waste after a wildfire, which further contributes to global warming and is less effective in cleaning a forest of wood waste.Both native Californians, Dede Smullen has prior experience in dealing with environmental policy as the president and CEO of Wildlife Urban Interface while Roger Smullen used to work in product market and development in the semiconductor industry."We were heart-broken by the loss of life, property and livelihoods that the wildfires in California caused, so we decided to do something about it. We're currently partnering on a 365-acre hazardous fuels reduction project in the San Francisco Bay Area, and it's the largest mobile pyrolysis project of its kind in the state. This is just the beginning as we expand our mobile pyrolysis capacity in 2024."

DEAL SIZE

$ 1-25 Million

urn:contentItem:6DMD-W891-JC11-13MF-00000-00Wis. Natural Resources Dept. Releases 2024 Air Quality Trends Report2024-12-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisWis. Natural Resources Dept. Releases 2024 Air Quality Trends ReportTargeted News ServiceMADISON, Wisconsin

(TNSres) -- The Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources issued the following news release on Dec. 10, 2024:

* * *

Includes Air Monitoring Data Through 2023

* * *

The Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources (DNR) today released its annual air quality trends report. This year's report covers 20 years of state air monitoring data for air pollutants regulated under the Clean Air Act, including ground-level ozone, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide, carbon monoxide, particle pollution and lead. The report presents data from the 2023 calendar year, including the historic 2023 Canadian wildfire smoke events.

According to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Center, 15 million hectares (about two million acres larger than the state of Wisconsin) burned in 2023 - more than six times the annual average in Canada.

"Five percent of the entire Canadian forest burned last year," said Gail Good, DNR Air Management program director. "During the multi-day air quality advisory in late June of last year, the air monitoring network measured some of the highest PM2.5 concentrations ever recorded in the state."

Wildfire smoke events in 2023 resulted in the DNR issuing 15 PM2.5 air quality advisories - almost five times higher than the average over the previous 12 years. PM2.5 advisories are issued when air quality has reached or is expected to reach the orange "unhealthy for sensitive groups" level on the Air Quality Index (AQI).

The design values used to assess PM2.5 concentrations are calculated over a three-year period. This year's Trends Report shows an increase in PM2.5 concentrations for the most recent period (2021-2023). Despite the jump caused by 2023's wildfire smoke, overall, PM2.5 concentrations have decreased 25% in the last 20 years, and all monitors measured concentrations below the 2012 federal air quality standards.

The report shows that over the last 20 years, statewide ozone concentrations have decreased by 15%. For decades, ozone concentrations have been dropping across the state. However, that trend has slowed. Last year's wildfire smoke contained ozone-forming pollutants, which, combined with recent warmer-than-usual summers, contributed to increased ozone concentrations.

As a result, the Lake Michigan shoreline area, including the Milwaukee area and parts of Sheboygan and Kenosha counties, continues to fall short of meeting the 2015 ozone standard. Wisconsin has implemented many programs that have reduced emissions of ozone-causing pollutants from power plants, industry and transportation in the state. However, these emission reductions have not resulted in the attainment of the 2015 ozone standard because most ozone-causing emissions are transported across state boundaries and are outside Wisconsin's control.

To better illustrate the latest trends, the DNR updated its Air Quality Trends Report Interactive StoryMap (https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/81082a373d334042b5381a86a34bb04b), which shows Wisconsin's air quality trends for each pollutant over the last 20 years. This tool provides an interactive visual to help convey the complex air quality data.

The 2024 Air Quality Trends Report, StoryMap and other historical reports are available on the DNR's Air Quality Trends webpage (https://dnr.wisconsin.gov/topic/AirQuality/Trends.html). Current Wisconsin air quality conditions can be found on the Wisconsin Air Quality Monitoring Data webpage (https://airquality.wi.gov/home/map).

* * *

Contact: Craig Czarnecki, Air Management Outreach Coordinator, 608/250-0945, Craig.Czarnecki@wisconsin.gov

urn:contentItem:6DSD-H433-RRJ9-52M8-00000-00Editor's pick: 2024's top 5 EPs2024-12-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 1Editor's pick: 2024's top 5 EPs

Opinion, The Echo

Editor's pick: 2024's top 5 EPs

Malcolm Todd, Dominic Fike and more round out the best short projects of the year

"When looking for a chill vibe, look no further. "JRNY" is consistently relaxed while being up-beat one song and slow on the next."

Elizabeth Villar

By Senna James

|

December 29, 2024 | 4:50pm MST

This year has been flooded by hundreds of new albums coming from popular artists such as Billie Eilish, Tyler, The Creator and Kendrick Lamar. But what about the EPs? The shorter projects call for a shorter list, so here are the five best EPs of 2024.

READ MORE: Editor's pick: The top 10 albums of 2024

5. "Sweet Boy pt. 1" by Malcolm Todd

Originally an EP at the start of the year, "Sweet Boy pt. 1" is composed of five alternative and indie songs and is an easy and fun listen. "4Me 4Me" is the best of the project, led by an addicting bounce and layered vocals.

Other tracks like "Ladygirl" and "Thailand" continue this vibe. Todd created an exciting experience on "Sweet Boy pt. 1" that is both danceable and chill, and it's absolutely worth a listen.

4. "Descanso" by Angela Muñoz

This EP cultivates a heavenly feel in every single song. The 20-minute listen is well worth it; it's an experience that envelopes you fully into the music. The way the project flows is similar to Steve Lacy's "The Lo-Fis:" The songs almost combine into one another while keeping their own style.

But what truly makes this EP great is Angela Muñoz's ethereal voice. "Forest Fire" is perhaps the best song, but "Descanso" as a whole is worth a listen.

3. "For You" by Troy Javelona

For those who enjoy a good R&B and soul feel, this EP is "For You." Each song flows into one another without sounding too much of the same, and though the project only lasts 17 minutes, it's still a joyful and complete ride.

Songs like "Dance" are groovy while songs like "Letting Go" are memorable and slower. The titular song "For You" is a good balance between the bright and joyful songs and the unhurried and more meaningful music within the EP.

2. "JRNY" by Jordan Ward and Joony

When looking for a chill vibe, look no further. "JRNY" is consistently relaxed while being upbeat one song and slow on the next. The layering of music and voices is what makes this EP stand out, especially in the track "Jealousy." Whether played in the background or listened to through AirPods, all the songs have the ability to change the atmosphere in the best way possible.

Ultimately, the EP gives off similarities to Brent Faiyaz's songs "Been away" and "Trust" while still having its own flavor. So for those who enjoy Faiyaz's work, this EP could expand your taste.

1. "14 minutes" by Dominic Fike

Dominic Fike's newest EP is the epitome of summer music. It is meant to be blasted in the car on a hot summer day, or - quite honestly - every day of the year.

While listening, each song stands out and is memorable: TikTok sensation "misses" is fun and upbeat, "hi grace" is a catchy autotune and piano-filled hit, and "coast2coast" is quick and thrilling.

If anything, the biggest downfall of the project is it being only 14 minutes. Yet, it only being that long is what makes it iconic. Every song hits and this EP is a good way to spend 14 minutes of any day.

Editor's note: The opinions presented in this review are the author's and do not imply any endorsement from The State Press or its editors.

Edited by Andrew Dirst, Sophia Braccio and Natalia Jarrett.

Reach the reporter at sjames51@asu.edu and follow @sennajames_ on X.

Like The State Press on Facebook and follow @statepress on X.

Senna JamesCommunity Editor

Senna is a sophomore studying journalism and mass communication with a minor in Spanish. This is her third semester with The State Press.
