urn:contentItem:680T-7NH1-DY07-D321-00000-00Update: 100% of New Jersey Forest Fire Contained2023-04-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisUpdate: 100% of New Jersey Forest Fire ContainedAndrew G. Simpson

A substantial wildfire in Manchester Township in New Jersey on federal, state and private property, which reached 3,859 acres in size, has been 100% contained, the state's forest fire service reported Thursday.

The New Jersey Forest Fire Service also said no injuries have been reported due to the massive forest fire.

The blaze, which started Tuesday, was located near Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst, a military installation in the state's pinelands.

New Jersey Air National Guard helicopters conducted water drops in support of the the firefighters on the ground.

About 170 homes in Manchester and Lakehurst were ordered evacuated, but residents have been told it is safe to return home. Roads that were closed have been reopened.

Yesterday afternoon about 20 structures were deemed under threat but by evening they were no longer in jeopardy from the fire.

"This fire exhibited extreme fire behavior," John Cecil, an assistant commissioner in the state's Department of Environmental Protection, told The Associated Press. "I don't mean to be dramatic, but this was a severe situation that these guys and gals managed to keep in a place and protect lives and property from that."

The cause of the fire is under investigation.

The state is experiencing high fire hazard conditions in multiple areas as warm, windy and dry weather continues.

Firefighters are still battling a forest fire near West Milford in the northern part of the state. That fire is about 250 acres in size and has been 30% contained.

A volunteer firefighter at a smaller Sussex County fire suffered cardiac arrest and died yesterday, fire officials reported.

urn:contentItem:6DC6-WCH1-DY7R-R1FN-00000-00New Engineering Research from Shenzhen University Described (GC-YOLOv9: Innovative smart city traffic monitoring solution)2024-11-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisENGINEERINGNew Engineering Research from Shenzhen University Described (GC-YOLOv9: Innovative smart city traffic monitoring solution)


2024 NOV 07 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Engineering Daily News -- Current study results on engineering have been published. According to news originating from Shenzhen, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "In urban smart city environments, traffic hazards can lead to catastrophic outcomes, including significant property losses and severe threats to public safety."


Funders for this research include Key Technologies Research And Development Program.
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Shenzhen University: "Conventional traffic monitoring systems are limited in terms of accuracy and speed, presenting significant challenges for real-time traffic surveillance. To tackle these challenges, this paper introduces the GC-YOLOv9 algorithm. Specifically, we have enhanced the YOLOv9 model by incorporating Ghost Convolution, markedly improving the model's perceptual abilities and detection accuracy. Furthermore, this study designed an integrated smart city framework that includes layers for service applications, the Internet of Things, edge processing, and data centers. By deploying the enhanced YOLOv9 model within this framework, our method achieved mAP@0.5 scores of 77.15 and 74.95 on the BDD100K and Cityscapes datasets, respectively, surpassing existing technologies."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Additionally, the potential applications of this method in public area fire safety management, forest fire monitoring, and intelligent security systems further underscore its significant value in improving the safety and efficiency of smart cities."
For more information on this research see: GC-YOLOv9: Innovative smart city traffic monitoring solution. Alexandria Engineering Journal, 2024,106():277-287. (Alexandria Engineering Journal - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/alexandria-engineering-journal/). The publisher for Alexandria Engineering Journal is Elsevier.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.aej.2024.07.004.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Ru An, College of Civil and Transportation Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Xiaochun Zhang, Maopeng Sun, Gang Wang.
Keywords for this news article include: Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, People's Republic of China, Asia, Engineering.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2024, NewsRx LLC

urn:contentItem:6DM0-F3V1-DXMP-K1GH-00000-00Author Karl Brauneis's New Book "The Blackwater Fire and the Men Who Fought It" Explores How the Blackwater Fire of 1937 Led to Lasting Changes in the Firefighting World2024-12-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisAuthor Karl Brauneis's New Book "The Blackwater Fire and the Men Who Fought It" Explores How the Blackwater Fire of 1937 Led to Lasting Changes in the Firefighting World

Lander, WY December 09, 2024 --(PR.com)-- Karl Brauneis, the 2004 recipient of the Paul Gleason National Fire Line Leadership Award, has completed his new book, "The Blackwater Fire and the Men Who Fought It: How Firefighters Turned Tragedy into New Beginnings": a comprehensive dive into the Blackwater Fire of 1937 in Wyoming that would forever alter the landscape of forest firefighting.



Author Karl Brauneis graduated in forestry and range management from Colorado State University, where he also ran for the Rams in cross country and track. He served in the US Forest Service as a timber cruiser, hotshot, smokejumper, incident commander, burn boss, Wyoming state fire trainer, Fremont County rural firefighter and forester for forty-four years in his conservation calling. Karl and his wife, Marilyn, have been blessed with three children and nine grandchildren, and currently reside in Lander, Wyoming.

"At 3:30 p.m. on August 21, 1937, the Blackwater Fire 'blew up' west of Cody, Wyoming, on the Shoshone National Forest," shares Brauneis. "Fifteen firefighters perish in the conflagration and more than forty are injured. Travel back in time to the horse and mule days of a frontier state and engage a forest fire in the rugged Absaroka Mountains. Gain the upper hand then see it all go so terribly wrong in a matter of seconds.

"How do we as individuals and organizations respond to disaster when tragedy strikes? Do we investigate to study and draw conclusions? Do we analyze the situation and file a report to be forgotten? Is that enough? Or do we say, 'No! There has to be more.' There must be a new beginning. The fallen cry out for it.

"Soon, young men will parachute from airplanes to hang up in trees and attack forest fires before they become the next tragedy. They will call themselves smokejumpers, and they will be the first to get there, and they will carry the Blackwater with them in the 'crack of silk' as they jump the big sky over our western forests."

Published by Covenant Books of Murrells Inlet, South Carolina, Karl Brauneis's new book not only honors the fallen heroes of the Blackwater Fire, but also explores the resilience and innovation that was born from that day of tragedy and loss. Drawing upon the author's own years of service as a forest firefighter, "The Blackwater Fire and the Men Who Fought It" reveals how tragedy can spur profound change, and how individuals and organizations can turn their deepest losses into the seeds for future growth.

Readers can purchase "The Blackwater Fire and the Men Who Fought It: How Firefighters Turned Tragedy into New Beginnings" at bookstores everywhere, or online at the Apple iTunes store, Amazon or Barnes and Noble.

Covenant Books is an international Christian owned and operated publishing house based in Murrells Inlet, South Carolina. Covenant Books specializes in all genres of work which appeal to the Christian market. For additional information or media inquiries, contact Covenant Books at 843-507-8373.

urn:contentItem:6D5S-47N1-JBSG-10M1-00000-00Smoke from burns, wildfire may be visible around N.M.2024-10-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisAPg. 7Smoke from burns, wildfire may be visible around N.M.Alaina Mencinger amencinger@sfnewmexican.com

Where there's smoke, there's usually fire.

There will be both this month and next when the Santa Fe National Forest performs prescribed burns near the Rio Chama Wilderness, the Forest Service announced Friday.

The first prescribed burn is planned for later this month about 1.5 miles east of Jemez Springs. That follows the late September ignition of a prescribed burn west of town near the Rancho de Chaparral Girl Scout Camp.

Two more planned burns, both several miles northeast of Llaves in a remote part of Rio Arriba County, could start by Nov. 7. Starting the fires is expected to take a couple of days, at which point fire crews will work to keep them contained.

Communities including Cuba, Abiquiú, Albuquerque and Jemez Springs might see smoke from the prescribed burns. People who are sensitive to smoke may be impacted and should take extra care, according to notifications sent out by National Forest officials.

A meeting is planned for Oct. 30 for community members to discuss the fires with forest fire managers. The meeting will begin at 6p.m. at the Regina Volunteer Fire Department, 923 Highway 96, in Cuba.

Prescribed burns are a way to reduce fuel to prevent more serious wildfires and benefit the overall ecosystem.

Not all burns are planned.

On Monday, the Santa Fe National Forest announced a wildfire had started near Jemez Springs. The cause of the 30-acre Porter Wildfire was still under investigation earlier this week, but it was not expected to harm people or property, according to a news release.

urn:contentItem:6F6C-3VT3-S7TT-80YW-00000-00Fired VA health workers reinstated, but new staff don't trust Trump and Musk2025-02-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisFired VA health workers reinstated, but new staff don't trust Trump and MuskCybele Mayes-Osterman, USA TODAY

WASHINGTON − The Department of Veterans Affairs has scrambled to reinstate some fired healthcare workers as new hires turn to other work out of fear they could be next to go in a future purge, elected officials and VA staffers said.

More than 1,000 VA employees were fired amid the sweeping layoffs of federal workers across the government, the department announced last week. Those fired included probationary employees – with two years or less on the job, depending on the position.

The firings are part of an ongoing effort by President Donald Trump and his top advisor, multibillionaire tech CEO Elon Musk, to radically shrink the size of the federal workforce. The abrupt firings have roiled the government and outraged critics who say workers in critical areas including nuclear security, forest fire prevention and bird flu response have been culled without warning.

This week, Democratic lawmakers said, at least two workers out of around a dozen fired from the Veterans Crisis Line, a suicide prevention hotline for veterans, were reinstated after the lawmakers intervened.

More: National Parks cutting hours, limiting services as Trump layoffs reduce staffing

Link to Image

More: Trump is firing federal workers who are not funded by taxpayers

VA Secretary Doug Collins took to social media this week to dispel what he called the "whopper" that any critical services would be cut.

"I'm here to tell you the truth," he said. "We're not cutting healthcare, we're not cutting benefits."

"Veteran care, benefits and beneficiaries will not be affected by VA’s personnel moves, which will allow us to redirect $98 million per year back toward health care, benefits and services for VA beneficiaries," a VA spokesperson said in an email to USA TODAY. VA leaders can request that employees be exempted from "probationary removal," and "more than 300,000 essential positions" were exempt from a Trump administration hiring freeze, the spokesperson said.

More: Tracking federal layoffs 2025: Impacted agencies include IRS, FAA, TSA and more

'Unnecessary stress'

Link to Image

But Democratic lawmakers and VA healthcare workers say the cuts and their impact on morale will affect VA care.

Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn., said the firing of VA personnel endangered the health of veterans and threatens to delay benefits, including those under the 2024 PACT Act that expanded health care and other benefits to vets exposed to burn pits and Agent Orange.

More: Elon Musk isn't actually in charge of DOGE, White House says

“It's a mess because it's having an effect on suicide prevention, mammograms, cardiology, a range of services, including benefits under the PACT Act,” said Blumenthal, the top Democrat on the Senate Veterans’ Affairs Committee. “We're putting pressure on the secretary of the VA to take some action to rescind the layoffs.”

One VA healthcare employee who works with high-risk veterans said some probationary employees on their team were fired last week before they were reinstated within a week. "The emotional distress that this is putting on veterans who are working to save lives is appalling," the employee, who asked to remain anonymous out of fear of retaliation, told USA TODAY.

Veterans in this worker's care are scared they will lose services, they said. "What we're doing is causing an unnecessary stress for the highest risk population." The employee said resignations among VA coworkers were "not uncommon."

More: As Elon Musk eyes Defense Department, conflicts of interest, accounting issues loom

The employee said they'd received an email ordering all staff back to the office as part of the Trump administration's directive to end telework for all federal employees.

But forcing providers long accustomed to working from home into disorganized, crowded spaces deprived the veterans they treat of privacy, the worker said.

Employees who didn't comply were threatened with harsh punishments including firing, they said. VA workers have also been warned that they would suffer "adverse consequences" for trying to disguise diversity programs or for using DEI-related language after Trump's blanket ban of DEI initiatives.

More: Musk's DOGE touted slashing an $8 billion contract. It actually cut $8 million.

Recent VA hires turned away, offers rescinded

The Trump administration has signaled that federal jobs related to national security and veterans' issues would not be subject to firings by Musk's Department of Government Efficiency. In some cases, like at the National Nuclear Security Agency, sweeping layoffs of federal workers with national security-related roles were rescinded days after they hit inboxes.

Musk appeared onstage at the Conservative Political Action Committee conference outside Washington, DC, on Thursday weilding a chainsaw to symbolize his intent to clear-cut what he describes as waste from the federal government.

Collins has suggested the department could go even further. "We're going to look for every efficiency," he told NewsNation in a Friday interview. "We're just getting started."

More: You’re …rehired? What we know about who is exempt from Donald Trump's mass firings

'Severe' VA medical staff shortages

A congressional aide familiar with the issue, speaking on condition of anonymity to discuss the issue in more detail, said their office had been in contact with recently hired VA employees who had their offers rescinded amid the federal hiring freeze.

Many were turning away from the VA towards higher-paid private sector jobs, fearing they would be laid off in a future wave of cuts.

More: GOP lawmakers get an earful on Elon Musk's DOGE

Government watchdogs have documented critically low staffing levels at VA healthcare facilities for at least a decade. Of 139 veterans' health facilities surveyed last year, only two were free of "severe occupational staffing shortages," according to an inspector general report. Medical officers and nurses have been in "severe shortage" since 2014, the report said.

"No one wants to work for the VA if they're treated like this," said Jake Pannell, a business representative for the National Federation of Federal Employees, which represents more than 110,000 people.

More: Acting VA secretary warns against disguising DEI programs targeted for termination

Although clinical staff were meant to be exempted from the cuts, Pannell said, people in positions that provide critical support to veterans' healthcare providers, like administrative assistants and program analysts, were among those terminated.

"If you don't give providers the tools or support or the staffing to do so, you're not going to be able to provide veteran care," he said.

Suicide prevention workers fired

One front-facing example is the Veterans' Crisis Line, an around-the-clock support hotline for veterans and their families. The crisis line maintains 1,100 responders stationed throughout three call centers, according to its website.

Collins also said reports that Crisis Line employees were fired were "just wrong," and a VA spokesperson said, "No Veterans Crisis Line responders have been laid off."

More: Boeing CEO says Musk 'helping in a big way' on timing of Air Force One planes

But Blumenthal and Sen. Tammy Duckworth, another Democratic member of the Veterans Affairs Committee, said some were caught up in the purge. A Veterans Crisis Line employee, speaking on condition of anonymity, also confirmed some of their coworkers were laid off and then reinstated.

“They were fired and the consequences have been really disastrous,” Blumenthal said. Veterans now face delays in speaking to counselors answering crisis calls, he said.

Duckworth said her staff had personally spoken with Crisis Line employees who were fired – around a dozen, according to her office.

More: 'Critical moment in history': Protests across US target Trump, Musk

After Duckworth inquired on their behalf, at least two of those workers were told that they were being reinstated, although they had yet to regain access to the system as of Wednesday morning, she told reporters.

"Why were these jobs ever even threatened in the first place? These are jobs in service of our veterans, and some of them are the ones who are most in crisis," Duckworth said.

Suicide rates for veterans remain much higher than the American population. After a decline in 2020, they began to climb again in recent years, with 6,407 veteran suicides in 2022.

Contributing: Tom Vanden Brook

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Fired VA health workers reinstated, but new staff don't trust Trump and Musk

urn:contentItem:6DJW-DVS1-F06S-P1GD-00000-00Rocket Lab Reports '2 Successful Launches Less than 24 Hours Apart'2024-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisRocket Lab Reports '2 Successful Launches Less than 24 Hours Apart'

Rocket Lab USA, Inc., a provider of launch services and space systems, on November 22 reported it successfully launched its 56th Electron mission, deploying five satellites to Low Earth Orbit for French Internet-of-Things (IoT) constellation operator Kineis.

The company said the "Ice AIS Baby" mission lifted-off from Rocket Lab Launch Complex 1 in Mahia, New Zealand at 4:55 pm on 25 November NZDT (03:55 UTC), successfully deploying five satellites to a 643 km low Earth orbit. The mission was Rocket Lab's 14th mission of 2024 and 56th launch overall. It also brought the total count of satellites deployed by Rocket Lab to 203, further cementing Electron's position as the leading small launch vehicle globally. The launch took place just 21 hours and 55 minutes after Rocket Lab completed a successful mission from Launch Complex 2 in Virginia, setting a new company record for fastest turnaround between launches.

Rocket Lab founder and CEO Sir Peter Beck said: "Two successful launches less than 24 hours apart from pads in different hemispheres. That's unprecedented capability in the small launch market and one we're immensely proud to deliver at Rocket Lab. Customers like Kineis are unlocking the potential of space and we're excited to give them the keys to do so with frequent, dedicated, and reliable small launch opportunities."

Kineis CEO Alexandre Tisserant, says: "The Kineis teams have once again demonstrated their technical capabilities as satellite operators by taking control of these five new satellites at a sustained launch rate. This achievement would not have been possible without Rocket Lab's Electron precision in placing our satellites in their planned positions. With 15 Kineis satellites now in orbit, we're one step closer to the full deployment of our dedicated IoT constellation for transmitting data in near-real time, anywhere on the globe. Congratulations to all our teams, who are doing an incredible job - and, let's not forget, a European first! We're equally enthusiastic about our second mission, AIS. In a rapidly consolidating market, Kineis is establishing itself as a sovereign European player, combining technological expertise and strategic independence. With our new AIS offering, we provide maritime players with enhanced visibility over their fleets, while ensuring higher data reliability."

The company added the "Ice AIS Baby" mission was the third of five dedicated Electron launches for Kineis, a company backed by private and public investors including the French government's space agency CNES (Centre National d'Etudes Spatiales) and CLS (Collecte Localisation Satellites), an international space-based solutions provider, to improve global IoT connectivity. The Kineis constellation is designed to make it possible to connect and locate any connected object anywhere in the world, enabling data transmission to users in near-real time, at low bit rates and with very low energy consumption. By enabling internet connection to the Earth's most remote locations, Kineis constellation can support forest fire detection, water resource management, infrastructure and energy network monitoring, transport and logistics tracking, and much more.

More information:

www.rocketlabusa.com

urn:contentItem:6DCC-10C1-JBTP-M543-00000-00US Forest Service appoints new forest supervisor for Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest2024-11-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSUS Forest Service appoints new forest supervisor for Okanogan-Wenatchee National ForestGabriel GarciaThe Wenatchee World, Wash.

Tara Umphries

Tara Umphries is the new forest supervisor for the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest.

WENATCHEE — The U.S. Forest Service announced the appointment of Tara Umphries as the new forest supervisor for the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest in a press release Oct. 24.

Umphries has been acting forest supervisor since July and will start the official position on Dec. 1.

Umphries will relocate to Wenatchee from Steamboat Springs, Colorado, where she was serving in the Rocky Mountain region as a special assistant to the regional forester, focused on shared stewardship and wildfire crisis strategy, according to the release.

“I’m honored to have the opportunity to work on such a diverse and complex forest with amazing people,” Umphries stated in the press release. “The people and partnerships on the Okanogan-Wenatchee have really stood out to me over the past several months while I’ve been acting in the position. I look forward to being able to support the work they are doing and the relationships the forest has with the Tribal nations, communities, partners, and the public it serves.”

Umphries has more than 20 years of experience with the U.S. Forest Service, according to the release. She started as a wildland firefighter, then moved into leadership roles, such as fuels program manager for the Willamette National Forest, fire planner for the Pacific Northwest Region 6, and district ranger for the Medicine Bow-Routt National Forest. Umphries also has experience in wildlife crisis strategy work, the release stated.

"Tara’s extensive experience and collaborative spirit will be a tremendous asset to the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest," stated Jacque Buchanan, regional forester for the Forest Service’s Pacific Northwest Region, in the release. "Her background in wildfire management and dedication to engaging with local communities resonate deeply with our region’s goal to build lasting partnerships. I am confident that her leadership will enhance our efforts to support both the needs of the community and the wildlife that depend on these lands.”

urn:contentItem:6C0M-0G61-DY7R-R07Y-00000-00Yunnan Normal University Researchers Add New Data to Research in Cancer [Temporal-Spatial Characteristics and Influencing Factors of Forest Fires in the Tropic of Cancer (Yunnan Section)]2024-05-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisCANCERYunnan Normal University Researchers Add New Data to Research in Cancer [Temporal-Spatial Characteristics and Influencing Factors of Forest Fires in the Tropic of Cancer (Yunnan Section)]


2024 MAY 10 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Cancer Daily -- New study results on cancer have been published. According to news reporting out of Kunming, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fires often cause many casualties and property losses, and it is important to explore the time and space laws of forest fires and the influencing factors."


Financial supporters for this research include Science And Technology Special Project of Southwest United Graduate School-major Projects of Basic Research And Applied Basic Research; National Natural Science Foundation of China; Yunnan Key Project of Basic Research; Yunnan Normal University's Research And Innovation Fund.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Yunnan Normal University: "The present study used the cities (prefectures) crossed by the Tropic of Cancer (Yunnan section) as the study area. Based on burned land data, a combination of natural factors, such as climate, topography, vegetation, and human activities, such as distance from settlements and population density, a binary logistic regression model, and a boosted regression tree model, were used to analyze the temporal-spatial characteristics and influencing factors of forest fires in 2000 to 2020. The following results were obtained: (1) During 2000-2020, the overall forest fire area in the study area showed a trend of fluctuating decline. The high incidence period of forest fires occurred in 2010. After 2010, the forest fire area in the study area was greatly reduced. (2) The forest fire area in the study area was greater in the east and less in the west."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The forest fire areas in Wenshan Prefecture and Honghe Prefecture in the east were larger, accounting for 68%, and the forest fire areas in Pu'er City, Lincang City, and Yuxi City in the west were smaller, accounting for only 32%. (3) The contribution rate of the average precipitation and average temperature factors ranked in the top two in the two driving force analysis models, which indicated that precipitation and temperature had a significant effect on the incidence of forest fires in the study area."
For more information on this research see: Temporal-Spatial Characteristics and Influencing Factors of Forest Fires in the Tropic of Cancer (Yunnan Section). Forests, 2024,15(4):661. (Forests - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/forests/). The publisher for Forests is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/f15040661.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Haichao Xu, Faculty of Geography, Yunnan Normal University, Kunming 650500, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Rongqing Han, Jinliang Wang, Yongcui Lan.

urn:contentItem:6D3N-WRW1-DY8S-B05R-00000-00Fire crews respond to lightning blaze burning in Eagle Cap Wilderness.2024-10-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSFire crews respond to lightning blaze burning in Eagle Cap Wilderness.Baker City Herald, Ore.

Wallowa-Whitman National Forest fire crews are responding to a 25-acre lightning sparked fire burning in the Eagle Cap Wilderness about 12 miles south of Wallowa.

The Bear Fire was reported Sept. 9, at 7 acres, according to the Blue Mountain Interagency Dispatch Center, and crews have been monitoring the blaze.

Dry, warm weather on Monday, Sept. 30, contributed to the fire's growth, and it produced smoke visible in the Wallowa Valley.

The fire is burning in steep terrain between Bear and Goat creeks, and is mainly smoldering on the ground, burning logs and forest litter, according to the Wallowa-Whitman. The fire likely will continue to burn as the dry, warm weather is forecast to continue for the next week.

The fire has not prompted any trail or area closures. People planning to travel in that part of the Eagle Cap Wilderness should call the Wallowa Mountains Office at 541-426-5546.

Under a Forest Service policy in place for more than 30 years, fire managers can monitor, rather than try to extinguish, lightning-caused fires in the Eagle Cap, Oregon's biggest federal wilderness at 360,000 acres.

Officials typically monitor such fires so long as they don't threaten private property or public safety.

urn:contentItem:6F8J-H8J3-S4VM-S519-00000-00Highland firemaster remembered: how a Clach, Caley and Inverness Thistle footballer rose up the ranks to inspire and influence a generation of Scottish firefighters2025-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisUK NEWS & SPORTS: SOCCER NEWSHighland firemaster remembered: how a Clach, Caley and Inverness Thistle footballer rose up the ranks to inspire and influence a generation of Scottish firefightersalasdair.fraser@hnmedia.co.uk (Alasdair Fraser)

It was a flair for football rather than burning ambition that first had Donald 'Donnie' Grant climbing up the fire service career ladder.

Back in the 1960s, the local fire service had a formidable team and the young striker's prowess made him an attractive recruit.

That talent in the 20-year-old's toes would see him play for all three town teams in the Highland League - Clachnacuddin (six years), Caledonian (two years) and Inverness Thistle (four years) - as well as many memorable fire service forays on the field of play.

Whatever breaks and good fortune football ability brought in his working life, those would be vindicated, though, by what he gave back.

As colleagues here testify, the positive influence he would come to exert would have a lasting positive impact on generations of younger, aspiring firefighters not only in the Highlands but throughout Scotland.

Mr Grant OBE, born in West Linton south of Edinburgh to a family with Highland roots, rose through the ranks to deputy firemaster and then firemaster by 1985.

It was a demanding role in the old Highland and Islands Fire Brigade and one that seldom promoted popularity, given the tough decision-making often requisite in the job.

Yet it says much of the man that past senior colleagues recall how he somehow managed to remain almost universally well-liked and thoroughly respected throughout the brigade.

A naturally modest man, Mr Grant told this newspaper not long before retiring in the mid-1990s: "I never joined the fire service thinking for a minute that I would be sitting here today (as firemaster). I never planned to be an officer.

"I think I've been very lucky and I would be the first person to realise that.

"I didn't set a goal that I was going to be firemaster. Most of the things just happened."

Mr Grant passed away peacefully at Raigmore Hospital on Sunday, February 2, at the age of 84. He was laid to rest by family, friends and colleagues in Inverness on Monday.

Inverness became home from an early age. At just six months old, his parents John and Christine Grant moved back north with older sisters Jean, Irene and Elizabeth, later joined by the arrival of youngest sibling, sister Jaye.

Schooled at Merkinch Primary, then the High School, the young Donnie was always sporty and football was a passion.

He became boot boy for Clach and went on to play for the 'juveniles' side Clach Rangers, with his promise attracting scouts from the rather larger Glasgow Rangers who wanted him to join their youth team.

Only 15 at the time, concerned dad John declined to give parental blessing.

Instead, he became an apprentice mechanical engineer with the firm Mackenzie and Co before the then-Northern Area Fire Brigade took notice of his football ability. He joined the day after finishing his apprenticeship in 1961.

As step-daughter Roslyn Main recounts: "At the time, they would say you didn't even get to be a fireman unless you could play football! He was sort of head-hunted to join the Fire Brigade on the basis of his football skills."

Mr Grant said in the Courier interview: "The fire service was looked on as a very secure job, which it still is today. That was the main reason I applied.

"One good thing about the fire service is that everybody starts as a firefighter. Nobody can come in at the middle. You start at the bottom and how far you get is entirely up to yourself."

Secure it might be, but this was no cushy number. Candidates to join needed good lung capacity, a head for heights and other entry tests including vertigo and claustrophobia checks.

Mr Grant had to pass arithmetic and dictation exams and prove he could carry a 12-stone man for 100 yards in a minute.

Satisfying all criteria, he was sent to the Scottish Fire Service Training School at Gullane near Edinburgh for three months, winning the firemaster's prize for best recruit.

Little did he know then, but by 1995, after stepping down as firemaster, he would return to the Gullane establishment as commandant, a role he fulfilled through to 2001.

He spent four years stationed in Thurso, returning to Inverness in 1971, rising to assistant then full divisional officer, then deputy firemaster in 1976.

As well as being a people person, he tirelessly attended fire brigade events and functions throughout the vast Highlands and Islands area - including a recruitment drive in Out Skerries off Shetland.

Another crucial role was overseeing the response to major critical incidents.

He later served as chairman of the Scottish branch of the Chief and Assistant Chief Fire Officers' Association; as advisor to the National Joint Council for Local Authorities' Fire Brigades; and on Cosla's proactive services committee.

Among the most infamous were major fires at the Inverness Railway Club, , Union Street's Methodist Church, a vast forest fire at Carrbridge, and the Aviemore Four Seasons Hotel blaze.

His closest personal escape in frontline service came at a house fire in Old Edinburgh Road when a cylinder in his breathing apparatus became stuck in the joists. Luckily, he was hauled to safety by a colleague.

He kept talk of the horrors of the job, the tragedies and despair of pulling bodies from buildings, mostly within colleague circles, while admitting in interview: "I have had more than my fair share."

Away from those distinguished working years, football remained an ever-present passion.

His exploits with Caley in 1964-65 brought a famous Scottish Cup victory over Raith Rovers and defeat to now defunct Third Lanark, with a goal from him in the 5-1 beating at Telford Street.

In the latter 80s, he served as referee and linesman.

He was also a prominent member of the UK-wide Fire Service Sports and Athletics Association, initially as a player, before heading up the organisation for a stint as president.

Not long before retirement, he said: "I enjoy going to my work. I have made many new friends throughout the UK and I have had a lot of happy times.

"Looking back, I definitely made the right move in joining the fire service all those years ago."

Above all, Mr Grant was a natural when it came to coaxing and looking after staff.

While he was awarded a richly-deserved OBE, also earning the Queen's Fire Service Medal (QFSM) for his dedicated service, he was just as comfortable conversing with the high and mighty as he was with colleagues and new recruits.

Ross Nixon, a retired Highland area group commander, recalls: "Donnie was an extremely well-respected and admired member of the Northern Area and Highlands and Islands fire brigade.

"That was not only for his meritorious service as firemaster but for his contribution and dedication to the fire service's sports and athletics association, particularly football, across the UK.

"Donnie's influence on the fire service continues to be evident today.

"The current chief and deputy chief of the Scottish Fire and Rescue service were recruit firefighters while Donnie was commandant of the fire service training school in Gullane, East Lothian from 1995 to 2001.

The values of fairness, hard work and integrity that were the hallmarks of Donnie's tenure as commandant therefore continue to be a thread woven into the fabric of today's Scottish service.

Retired John Cheadle, a former divisional commander based in Inverness, served while Mr Grant was deputy firemaster to Bill Shand.

"The first thing that comes to mind when I think of Donnie is football!" Mr Cheadle said.

"While he was firemaster, he was president of the sports and athletics association for the whole of the UK and a real driving force in it.

"He was deputy when our Fire Brigade football team won the UK national championships. We only had about 60 or 70 to choose from, but they won against brigades of 3000 or more.

"Before I came up here, if you applied for a job as a firefighter, I'm told it helped greatly if you had a talent with a ball at your feet!

"Thankfully, Donnie really did. He went on to enjoy a fine career and became a very good deputy, then firemaster after Bill Shand retired, in my time.

"He was very popular, which is saying something for someone who serves as firemaster as you sometimes have to make some not very nice decisions.

"Donnie was a very friendly, chirpy character and seemed to get on with everybody."

The Scottish Fire and Rescue Service's local senior officer for Highland, area commander Michael Humphreys, said: "Our thoughts are with Donald Grant's family at this difficult time.

"Donald was a well-respected firefighter and officer, having served as Firemaster of the Highland and Islands Fire Brigade and Commandant of the Scottish Fire Service Training School in Gullane.

"Known as Donnie to many of his friends, he was responsible for shaping a great many fire service careers.

"He will be sadly missed by his family and former colleagues in the service."

Mr Grant is survived by wife Pat, children Rosalyn, Jenny and Don and his beloved grandchildren Brittany, Shaun, Ellie, Amy, Teigan and Isla.

Donnie Grant OBE, former Highlands and Islands firemaster.

urn:contentItem:6DD7-BDX1-JC85-V12G-00000-00<published>2024-11-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:21:36Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>MAIN</positionSection><positionSequence>Pg. 9A</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Dry conditions on both coasts fuel several wildfires</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>Staff</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline><highlight><bodyText><p>UNITED STATES</p></bodyText></highlight></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fire crews battled small wildfires across the Northeast U.S. on Monday, including a blaze in New York and New Jersey that killed a parks employee over the weekend and postponed Veterans Day plans. A quarter-inch of rain fell overnight from Sunday into Monday in a forest area straddling the border between the states, giving a slight respite to firefighters.</p><p>The fire is one of several burning on the East Coast amid a lack of much rainfall since September.</p><p>An employee of the New York State Parks, Recreation, and Historic Preservation Department who was assisting firefighting crews died Saturday when he was hit by a falling tree.</p><p>In California, firefighters continued making progress against a wildfire northwest of Los Angeles in Ventura County that broke out Wednesday and quickly exploded in size because of dry, warm and gusty Santa Ana winds.</p><p>The fire in Ventura County north of Los Angeles prompted thousands of residents to flee their homes and was 36% contained as of Monday. The fire’s size remains around 32 square miles. That fire has destroyed more than 170 structures, most of them homes, officials said. The cause is under investigation.</p><p>Across the country on the New Jersey and New York border, the 4.7 square-mile fire dubbed the Jennings Creek Wildfire was 10% contained as of midmorning Monday, and 25 structures were considered threatened, although no evacuations had been ordered, said the New Jersey Forest Fire Service.</p><p>At least four other wildfires in central to northern New Jersey were mostly or completely contained as of Monday.</p><p>In West Milford, New Jersey, a Veterans Day ceremony was postponed to later in the month because of the firefighting effort, said Rudy Hass, the local Veterans of Foreign Wars of the U.S. commander.</p><p>“Many of those personnel currently engaged with the fires are veterans themselves, and right now we need to keep them in our thoughts as they spend many hours, day and night, doing all they can in order to protect our great communities in that area,” he posted online.</p><p>In Massachusetts, one wildfire among several fueled by powerful wind gusts and dry leaves had burned around 400 acres in the Lynn Woods Reservation, a municipal park extending across about 3.4 square miles in Lynn, which is 10 miles north of Boston.</p><p>The Lynn Fire Department cited “a dry spell we have not seen during this time of year in many years.”</p><p>Before Sunday night, the last measurable rainfall in New Jersey occurred on Sept. 28.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:6DD8-RK21-DY7R-R4TN-00000-00University of Saskatchewan Reports Findings in Climate Change (Perspective: Dimensions of Environment and Health in Arctic Communities)2024-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEUniversity of Saskatchewan Reports Findings in Climate Change (Perspective: Dimensions of Environment and Health in Arctic Communities)


2024 NOV 12 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- New research on Climate Change is the subject of a report. According to news reporting from Saskatoon, Canada, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "In the Arctic, environment and health are linked in myriad ways. A key emphasis has been on numerous long-lived contaminants in traditional foods, particularly marine mammals, and their well-documented impacts on human, animal and environmental health ('One health approach')."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University of Saskatchewan, "More recent concerns for Indigenous communities focus on the (side) effects of the switch to a modern, processed diet, which is accompanied by a loss of tradition and emerging health impacts. Furthermore, the availability of traditional foods is increasingly threatened by the impacts of climate change, which also causes the emergence and spread of new and old diseases, such as anthrax. Climate change, including thawing permafrost and new forest fire regimes, threatens the built environment and infrastructure. In particular, well-built, planned, and healthy housing is urgently needed, given that much time is spent indoors. Health care, particularly for remote and Indigenous communities, is sparse, and often ignores traditional knowledge and local languages. Indigenous communities in the Arctic continue to suffer from marginalization, resource colonization/extraction, and the impacts of racism. Recent examples of the green energy transition, such as in Norway, continue a pattern of ignoring Indigenous rights and lifestyles."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Overall, the connection between environment and health in the Arctic is multifaceted and complex, and investigations and solutions ought to embrace an interdisciplinary and holistic approach toward improving Environmental and Human Health in the region."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Perspective: Dimensions of Environment and Health in Arctic Communities. Environment & Health, 2023;2(1):3-10.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Bonita Beatty, College of Arts and Sciences, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan S7N 5A2, Canada. Additional authors for this research include Rainer Lohmann, Jessica Graybill, Elena Grigorieva, Ketil Lenert Hansen and Anu Soikkeli.
Keywords for this news article include: Saskatoon, Canada, North and Central America, Climate Change, Global Warming.

urn:contentItem:6FVP-B8C3-RRXN-H0YR-00000-00A novel optimal distributed strategy for time-varying formation tracking control in large-scale robot swarms2025-11-15T08:21:36Z2025-11-15T08:21:36ZLexisNexisA novel optimal distributed strategy for time-varying formation tracking control in large-scale robot swarms

Publisher’s NoteSpringer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

The present study aims to assess a fully distributed optimal time-varying formation algorithm for a leader–follower system, which is characterized by linear second-order dynamics and operates under a dynamic communication topology with time-varying and uncertain communication weights. In this case, the communication topology’s weights may be negative, unlike most other conventional studies where the communication weights should have positive and constant values. Thus, the proposed algorithm resists changes in communication weights. The primary goal of the control strategy is to minimize control effort while ensuring fast convergence to the desired formation. Additionally, the algorithm allows agents to continuously adjust key formation parameters, such as orientation, centroid, and scale, providing flexibility and adaptability during formation. Information about the desired trajectory, rotational velocity, and scale of the formation is given to only one of the directly connected followers through a virtual leader to realize time-varying formation tracking. The designed controller, which is considered fully distributed, can be applied to modern commercial large-scale systems because it does not require information about the eigenvalues of the communication topology. Numerical simulations are implemented to validate the theoretical findings.

IntroductionThe cooperative control of multi-agent robotic systems has captured significant interest because of its extensive applications in fields such as localization, load transportation, forest fire monitoring, agricultural observation, and maritime rescue1, 2, 3, 4, 5–6. Compared to single and expensive robots, a group of small and inexpensive robots that cooperatively exchange information with each other to obtain a specific objective can perform their assigned tasks more effectively and better. Various collaborative control algorithms, such as consensus7, formation8, 9–10, flocking11, and aggregation12, have been created or developed based on specific objectives. Formation control has been evaluated as a conventional and significant application in the field of collaborative control13, 14–15. The formation control problem can be divided into two main subproblems16: shape and maneuver control. Formation shape control seeks to achieve a fixed and predetermined geometric pattern by a group of agents. Formation shape control is utilized even in various biological systems where a regular geometric structure should be formed so that the agents are hypothesized to be cells or microorganisms17.

The maneuver control problem emphasizes that robots can change the orientation, centroid, and scale of the desired formation when necessary while maintaining an appropriate geometric pattern18. This issue is highly applicable in the real world. For example, the formation scale should change while keeping its geometric pattern unchanged when robots traverse a narrow path.

Methods for achieving formation have focused on strategies based on virtual structures19, behaviors20, artificial potential fields21, 22–23, and consensus24, 25–26, each of which has strengths and weaknesses. For instance, strategies based on virtual structure and behavior benefit from strong robustness. However, the first strategy imposes a large computational burden, while the second strategy is highly complicated for performing theoretical analysis. In addition, the artificial potential field is regarded as a conventional method for achieving the desired formation due to its potential for implementation and clear physical meaning despite its lack of robustness. The consensus-based strategy has attracted much attention due to its appropriate scalability, low computational load, and strong robustness. Based on the literature, the theoretical works are considered extremely rich despite their inability to handle the formation maneuvers, considering the change in scale and experiencing rotation and translation simultaneously.

In consensus-based formation, agents agree on a desired formation reference by exchanging information with their neighbors to maintain a minor deviation from it. The formation problem becomes formation tracking when the formation reference is regarded as the state of a virtual or physical agent. This agent, known as the leader, is called maneuvering when it has a nonzero control input. It is worth noting that the abovementioned works examined the problem of achieving fixed formations such as pentagonal23 or triangular26 formations. However, time-invariant formation methods cannot meet some needs in real-world scenarios such as cooperative detection and surveillance27, 28–29. Therefore, time-varying formation strategies have garnered significant interest owing to their benefits, including adaptability, reliability, enhancement of resource productivity, and task allocation29,30. Furthermore, the theoretical results obtained from the time-varying formation can be utilized for the issues of fixed formation and consensus control. As far as we know, the problem of time-varying formation tracking with a maneuvering virtual leader, where the formation changes scale, rotation, and translation within a switching topology, is still open. This challenge serves as the primary motivation for the present study.

Several studies have explored algorithms for handling rotational and translational maneuvers and scale adjustments within formations. However, addressing these changes within a switching communication topology remains a significant challenge. For instance, Chen et al.31 introduced a control method allowing agents to maneuver through mismatched angles, facilitating both rotational and translational movement. Similarly, Zhao18 developed an affine formation control algorithm for multi-agent systems, enabling dynamic adjustments in the formation structure. Furthermore, Chen et al.32 guaranteed global convergence for rigid formations under angle maneuvering, effectively handling complex geometric changes. While these studies have addressed various aspects of formation maneuvering with fixed communication topologies, our research takes a step further by focusing on fully distributed formation control within a switching communication topology.

To date, significant results have been achieved in the area of time-varying formation control. For example, Zhang et al.33 proposed a time-varying formation method based on average consensus theory specifically for underactuated systems. Moreover, Feng et al.34 created a discrete-time distributed algorithm designed to ensure time-varying formation tracking even when time-varying faults occur in linear multi-agent systems (MASs). Furthermore, Zhang et al.35 derived an optimal time-varying formation control law for omnidirectional robotic systems employing an adaptive fuzzy method based on output feedback. Furthermore, Zhang et al.36 presented the problem of time-varying formation tracking in the presence of multiple leaders using an adaptive control protocol. In another study, Wang et al.37 utilized an adaptive control protocol for swarm systems with linear dynamics to realize time-varying formation in the presence of a switching topology. To this end, the control gain matrix was achieved by solving a linear matrix inequality, and the agents could rotate with a certain angular velocity. However, all of the studies above suffer from a fundamental limitation: a positive lower bound should be established for the communication weights among the agents. In addition, none of the abovementioned studies support the change in the formation scale. Furthermore, Wang et al.37 indicated that agents leave the desired formation and that the algorithm fails when the angular velocity of the agents that reach a formation increases or decreases suddenly for various reasons. Applying the linear matrix inequality to obtain the control gain is considered an inefficient method because it imposes a large computational load, especially when there is a large-scale problem. It is worth noting that several studies, including16,18, and32, have investigated formation control with scale adjustments and negative interaction weights. However, our work stands out by tackling the challenges of switching communication topology. Furthermore, in the referenced works, the weights of the communication links in the network topology are treated as fixed values. In contrast, in this study, the weights are considered time-varying and uncertain.

Ubiquitous faults or even cyber-attacks can create faults while transmitting information between network agents. The information in a networked system is transmitted through a weighted graph, which is known as communication topology. Thus, the weights in such a communication graph can change in the event of a fault to form an uncertainty in the weights. Accordingly, the weights in the communication graph can increase, decrease, or even change signs. A critical question is whether conventional consensus algorithms or consensus-based formation strategies can still achieve their defined objectives in the presence of negative weights that vary over time. It is noteworthy that most of the aforementioned algorithms or formations presented to date have restrictive hypotheses. For instance, asymptotic consensus can be achieved by ensuring that the weights in the communication graph are part of a compact set with a positive lower limit38, 39–40, or they ought to be regarded as constant41,42. Based on the literature, achieving a time-varying formation when there is substantial uncertainty in the weights of the communication topology so that the weights can change signs is regarded as another motivation for conducting the current study.

On the other hand, the rate of convergence is deemed a valid metric for analyzing the efficacy of a consensus protocol. Based on the results of some studies, the rate of convergence is directly related to the algebraic connectivity, described as the second smallest eigenvalue of the communication graph’s Laplacian matrix. An increase in the amount of algebraic connectivity increases the convergence rate in the same proportion43,44. Inspired by this fact, researchers have aimed to increase the convergence rate by enhancing algebraic connectivity45,46. However, increasing the convergence rate in this method necessitates identifying a communication graph with significant algebraic connectivity, which forces the control algorithm to leave the fully distributed state because the algebraic connectivity is calculated from the network’s Laplacian matrix. In fact, the Laplacian matrix in the entire network of agents should be known to the designer in advance, meaning access to global information about the communication network, which contradicts the philosophy of fully distributed control47. Accordingly, this paper proposes a fully distributed consensus-based formation algorithm that achieves a high rate of convergence without relying on the approach of algebraic connectivity maximization. This is considered another contribution of the work.

In addition, researchers have sought to increase the number of robots in multi-agent robotics systems due to technological progress in the fields of electric motors, solar cells, and battery capacity. A swarm robotics problem emerges when there are a large number of robots48. Typically, robots are hypothesized to be relatively simple with limited computing resources and communication capabilities, such as those presented in49,50. Generally, there are two main control methods for large-scale swarm robotics systems: the centralized control method and distributed control architecture. In the first method, a preselected robot or a ground station makes control decisions for the entire robotics system, such as Crazyswarm, which is controlled by a central computer51. However, in the second method, collective decisions are made by exchanging information with the neighbors of each agent. Centralized control methods fail to perform efficiently for large-scale robotics teams due to data traffic and insufficient channel resources. Accordingly, Borrelli and Keviczky52 designed a distributed controller for a large-scale swarm robotics system containing one hundred robots to bring the agents to a desired formation. However, the control algorithms proposed in48, 49, 50, 51–52 are not considered fully distributed, as they require calculating algebraic connectivity and the Laplacian matrix to determine specific control parameters. The present study aims to design a fully distributed formation strategy for large-scale swarm robotics systems containing one hundred robots in the presence of poor communication conditions, such as changes in communication weights and the existence of uncertainty.

It is essential to highlight that optimizing formation control is just as crucial as its initial achievement, leading researchers to focus on distributed optimal formation strategies. In53, the authors developed time-varying formation control protocols for MASs, proposing both leaderless and leader-following strategies to minimize control energy consumption and enhance cooperative performance using a Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) approach. However, it was not fully distributed due to reliance on the Laplacian matrix’s minimum non-zero eigenvalue. In54, collision-risk-based event-triggered strategies were introduced for optimal formation control in mobile MASs, while55 explored optimal control for integrator chain MASs with strongly convex local cost functions, aiming to minimize global costs. The study in56 presented a collaborative approach for unmanned surface vehicles (USVs) with six degrees of freedom, considering input saturation, and57 tackled second-order stochastic MASs with unknown nonlinear dynamics using a fuzzy logic-based adaptive control strategy integrated with an actor-critic architecture. Furthermore, Huang et al.58 proposed a generic distributed optimal formation control algorithm for second-order MASs, though all the studies53, 54, 55, 56, 57–58 assumed a fixed network topology. To address the challenges of switching network topologies, Gao et al.59 introduced a novel data-driven approach for cooperative adaptive control in leader–follower MASs under a switching network topology. Despite these advancements, a fundamental limitation in works53, 54, 55, 56, 57, 58–59 is their inability to handle formations with dynamic scaling, and all these strategies used positive constant weights in their network topology. In contrast, our work introduces uncertainty into the topology, allowing for unknown and potentially negative weights.

Designing controllers for large-scale swarm robotic systems poses significant challenges compared to small-scale systems. Traditional centralized control algorithms, while effective for smaller networks, become computationally prohibitive as the system size increases, while decentralized approaches often yield suboptimal performance in complex, large-scale environments60,61. Two critical questions arise in this context62: (1) How can control performance be optimized while satisfying system constraints? (2) How can scalability be ensured in the presence of a time-varying communication network? Furthermore, many existing control methods rely on linear matrix inequalities (LMIs) for their computations. Although LMIs are powerful tools, their practicality diminishes in large-scale systems as the dimensionality of the problem grows, making the LMIs unsolvable for large-scale networks63. To overcome these challenges, this research proposes a novel controller design that avoids reliance on LMIs, ensuring computational feasibility and scalability. The fully distributed approach introduced here maintains system performance while addressing the complexities of dynamic and uncertain environments inherent to large-scale swarm robotic systems.

This study aims to review the problem of fully distributed time-varying maneuver formation for 2D double integrator systems with dynamic communication topology. Accordingly, communication links between agents can be destroyed, new links can form over time, and the communication link weights are hypothesized to be uncertain and to change over time. The proposed strategy is carefully designed to achieve the desired formation using both the minimum and maximum functions concurrently. Compared to existing work, the key contributions of this study are as follows:

Unlike conventional consensus algorithms, such as those in38, 39, 40, 41–42, which require fixed communication topology weights with a positive lower bound to achieve asymptotic consensus, the consensus algorithm proposed in this paper eliminates these restrictive conditions. It accommodates a switching communication topology with time-varying and uncertain weights, allowing the weights to even change sign from positive to negative.

Compared to the results published in33, 34, 35, 36–37, the proposed formation strategy can realize formation maneuvers by changing the rotation and formation scale simultaneously. This scenario is rarely addressed in the literature.

Compared with other methods such as52, the proposed architecture can effectively transform large-scale formation systems into consensus-based systems in the presence of poor communication conditions, such as changes in the communication weights between agents. Furthermore, the process of reaching an agreement among agents is marked by a rapid rate of convergence.

Unlike the approaches in43, 44, 45–46, the convergence rate in this work does not depend on maximizing algebraic connectivity. Instead, the proposed strategy utilizes distinct working modes—Tracker, Following, and Cross—during the formation process. Once an agent switches to the Following mode, it exclusively tracks neighbors in the Tracker mode and removes itself from further comparisons with other agents in future iterations of the proposed algorithm. This targeted approach significantly accelerates the convergence process.

The subsequent sections of the study are structured as follows: section “Preliminaries and problem formulation” addresses the preliminaries and outlines the problem formulation. Section “Main results” covers the main results and introduces the proposed time-varying formation strategy. The numerical simulations employed to verify the theoretical results are detailed in section “Numerical simulations”. Accordingly, two examples are presented, one for the large-scale formation problem containing one hundred robots in the presence of poor communication conditions and the other for the time-varying maneuver formation problem. Ultimately, the conclusion is delivered.

Remark 1

This paper introduces a consensus-based formation algorithm that operates within two coordinate systems: the consensus coordinate system, denoted by , and the formation coordinate system, denoted by . In this framework, ​ represents the position of agent in the consensus coordinate system, with the initial conditions of all agents embedded in the variables at the algorithm’s outset. Similarly, represents the position vector of each agent in the formation coordinate system. The primary objective of the algorithm is to compute a series of control set points, ​, for each agent within the communication network. By following these control set points, the variables converge to a common value in the consensus coordinate system, achieving consensus. Once consensus is achieved, the position vector of each agent aligns with its corresponding desired position vector , resulting in the realization of the desired geometric pattern.

The MAS is organized into two primary layers: the guidance layer and the inner layer (Fig. 1). The system comprises agents, where the guidance layer includes the virtual leader, designated as agent , and the inner layer consists of the follower agents, represented as . Successful formation tracking depends on the coordinated interaction between both layers. The virtual leader in the guidance layer provides the overall trajectory or target formation, while the follower agents in the inner layer adjust their positions, velocities, and other states using information from both the virtual leader and their neighboring agents to maintain the desired formation. These layers work together to ensure the entire system operates harmoniously to achieve the prescribed objectives.Fig. 1

MAS control layers.

Assumption 1

The communication topology among followers is assumed to be bidirectional, while information exchange between adjacent layers is unidirectional.

Assumption 2

It is assumed that the minimum system dwell time, , is adequately long to enable the implementation of all required control inputs. This ensures that converges to at discrete time instances where is a positive integer.

Main results

Here, a fully distributed consensus strategy is designed to build a consensus among the s in the consensus coordinate system. The proposed consensus strategy seeks to generate a series of points in the state space to guarantee consensus by the agents obtaining the points. Based on the consensus strategy, equation should be established after the end of each execution by applying the control input to agent when and the vector generated by the consensus strategy for agent is described as . The transmission of information within the communication network will be modeled in the subsequent section. The consensus strategy and control input are then introduced.

Modeling the information transmission in the communication channel

It is hypothesized that the information transmission in the communication channel evolves due to the presence of unwanted faults. Thus, time-varying communication weights are regarded as uncertain, allowing for the possibility of negative values. The communication weights in the faulty network are expressed as where is regarded as an unknown function in the interval from zero to infinity when describes the main weights in the communication network without uncertainty. In fact, describes the damaged weights in the communication channel of each agent with its neighbors due to a fault in information transmission.

Remark 7

A time-varying communication network arises from two primary factors: (1) a switching communication topology caused by the breaking and formation of links, and (2) time-varying interactions between neighboring agents, resulting in changes to the weights of the communication graph edges over time. In this paper, both factors are considered simultaneously, resulting in the creation of a complex time-varying network.

Active modes in each execution of the proposed strategy

Each agent has the ability to operate in one of three operating modes: Tracker, Following, or Cross. These modes are delineated as follows:

Tracker mode: All of the agents are placed in this mode when strategy (5) starts to be implemented, meaning that every agent within the communication network should decide to select one of Eqs. (5-Ι) to (5-ΙΙΙ) to update , considering its position relative to its neighbors and based on the sets , , and .

Following mode: Some agents in the tracker mode gradually reduce the difference in each of their components () to zero with the corresponding components of their neighbors () when agents implement strategy (5). To this end, agent shifts to the following mode from the tracker mode. This agent no longer needs to decide which of Eqs. (5-Ι) to (5-ΙΙΙ) should be implemented to update in subsequent executions of the abovementioned consensus strategy. Instead, it imitates the behavior of its neighboring agents, which reduces their difference from to zero. Accordingly, in subsequent executions of the proposed consensus strategy, regardless of the value takes for its update, takes the same value for its update.

Cross mode: During certain times of implementing strategy (5), one of the neighboring agents in the tracker mode seeks to update its value to that of belonging to its neighbor based on Eq. (5-Ι), considering the definition of the tracker mode. Simultaneously, agent , which is considered to be a neighbor of agent , aims to increase its value to that of based on Eq. (5-II), resulting in a Cross state. At this time, one agent, either or , is selected randomly to keep its or value constant and allows its neighboring agent to increase its or value to match that of the other agent. As a result, the agents transition from the tracker to the cross mode.

Remark 10

The strategy proposed here significantly reduces the convergence time since the agents , which are in the following mode, only need to employ the value of their neighbors, which are in the tracker mode, to update their . In fact, agent immediately selects the same value for its that agent chooses for its own .

Remark 12

In the literature, fully distributed consensus strategies often employ adaptive weight designs to eliminate reliance on global parameters, such as the smallest eigenvalue of the graph Laplacian, as demonstrated in64,65. These adaptive designs enable agents to dynamically adjust their weights, enhancing robustness and accelerating convergence. However, not all consensus algorithms rely on adaptive weights. For example, the algorithm in66 achieves global asymptotic min-consensus for second-order multi-agent systems using a time-derivative-based design, while the max-consensus algorithm in67 determines the maximum value of agents’ initial states through purely local communication. These alternative approaches offer significant insights into achieving efficient and reliable consensus while eliminating the constraints associated with adaptive weights.

The explanations provided about work modes are presented as a visual example to help readers better understand the mode allocation mechanism.

Remark 14

The key difference between the optimal control scheme in Eq. (6) and Model Predictive Control (MPC) is that the former uses a one-time offline optimization, applying a precomputed control law without iterative computation, whereas MPC continuously optimizes at each time step, which can be computationally intensive. The proposed control scheme is computationally efficient and straightforward to implement, making it particularly attractive for large-scale systems or those with limited processing capacity. Since it does not rely on solving optimization problems during execution, it avoids potential issues such as timing delays or numerical instability that can arise in real-time optimization. These features contribute to the consistency and reliability of the control process, especially in systems with stable dynamics where frequent real-time adjustments are not critical.

Figure 5 shows the control architecture of the proposed consensus strategy. The proposed control architecture includes guidance and internal layers. In the first layer, the virtual leader generates and provides the desired trajectory to the follower . The second layer contains the followers and their interaction network. As illustrated, and generated by strategy (5) enter the mode determining unit so that its output is considered to be the mode number (M⋅N⋅). The active mode is regarded as Tracker, Following, or Cross when M⋅N⋅ = 1, 2, or 3, respectively. The control input is generated utilizing the mode number and feedback from so that and enter the communication network to be available for follower .Fig. 5

Architecture and control layers in the proposed strategy.

Numerical simulations

To demonstrate the effectiveness of the theoretical findings, two case studies are presented. In the first case study, a swarm robotics system containing one hundred robots is presented, and its results are compared with those reported by others. In the second case study, the suggested algorithm is implemented in a leader–follower system incorporating a virtual leader to address the time-varying formation tracking issue under a switching communication topology with time-varying, unknown, and uncertain communication weights.

The proposed consensus-based formation maneuvering algorithm operates in the following phases:

Primary formation: In this phase, the robots move in the 2D plane by employing the proposed algorithm to obtain the desired primary formation from a randomly given initial posture.

Translating and rotating: During this phase, the virtual leader generates the desired trajectory by simultaneously translating and rotating the formation.

Scaling: In this phase, the robotics system increases or decreases the formation scale while maintaining its configuration.
